       return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {            const tx = db.transaction(this.storeName, 'readwrite');            const store = tx.objectStore(this.storeName);            let request;            switch(operation) {                case 'add':                    request = store.add(item);                    break;                case 'put':                    request = store.put(item);                    break;                case 'delete':                    request = store.delete(item.id); .kgold {
color: #555;
background: linear-gradient(to top right, #F0B27A, #FDE184, #F0B27A);

position: relative;

50%{background-color:#FDE184;}

.shine::before {

position: absolute;

left: -50%;

height: 200%;
background: linear-gradient(

rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.15),
rgba(255, 255, 255, 0)
);
transform: rotate(-45deg);
animation: shine 2.8s linear infinite;
}
@keyframes shine {
from {

}
to {
transform: translateX(150%) translateY(150%) rotate(-45deg);
}
}

.kmenu {
background-color: #202123;
color: #FFFFFF;
border: 0.06rem solid #4D4D4F;
border-radius: 0.625rem;
box-shadow: 0 0.125rem 0.375rem rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.15);
display: none;
min-width: 12.5rem;
padding: 0.75rem 0;
position: absolute;
z-index: 1000;
}
.kmenu::before {
content: â€œâ€;
position: absolute;
top: 0rem;
bottom: 0rem;
left: -6rem;
right: 0rem;
pointer-events: auto;
z-index: -1;
}
.kmenu::after {
content: â€œâ€;
position: absolute;
top: 1rem;
left: -1.25rem;
border-style: solid;
border-width: 0.625rem 0.625rem 0.625rem 0.625rem;
border-color: transparent #202123 transparent transparent;
}
.kmenu li {
display: block;
padding: 0.5rem 1.5rem;
text-align: left;
user-select: none;
display: flex;
align-items: center;
}
.kmenu li:hover {
background-color: #273746;
cursor: pointer;
}

main div.items-end>div:first-child {
user-select: none;
max-width: 30px;
cursor: pointer;
}

nav {
position: relative;
}

.checkbutton {
height: 20px;
margin-left: auto;
margin-right: -35px;
padding-left: 10px;
}
.checkbutton:hover {
cursor: pointer;
}
.checked path {
fill: #30D158;
}
.checked circle {
transform: translateX(14px);
transition: transform 0.2s ease-in-out;
}

.largescreen .md\:max-w-2xl, .largescreen .lg\:max-w-xl, .largescreen .xl\:max-w-3xl {
max-width: unset;
}
.largescreen .lg\:px-0 {
padding-left: 25px;
padding-right: 50px;
}
@media (min-width:1024px) {
.largescreen form.stretch {
max-width: 85%;
}
}
.largescreen div.items-end>div.text-xs {
top: -20px;
left: -5px;
margin-left: unset;
-webkit-transform: unset;
transform: unset;
position: absolute;
}
.largescreen img {
width: 653px
}

.fullscreen {
max-width: 0px;
}
.btn-neutral {
cursor: pointer;
}

#new-chat-button + div, #expand-sidebar-bottom-button, #nav-toggle-button, #user-menu ~ div {
display: none !important;
max-height: 0 !important;
}

.navdate {
font-size: 0.75rem;
padding-right: 0.5rem;
}
nav.flex div.overflow-y-auto a.hover\:pr-4 {
padding-right: unset;
}
nav.flex div.overflow-y-auto {
scrollbar-width: thin;
}
.gptm {
position: absolute;
top: 1.15rem;
left: 0.95rem;
font-size: 0.7rem;
font-weight: bold;
color: white;
}
.knav li::after {
content: â€œâ€;
display: block;
height: 1px;
background: linear-gradient(to right, transparent, #5e5e5e, transparent);
}

#nmenuid_ap {
color: #00bf78;
}

nav.flex .transition-all {
position: unset;
}

.hide {
display: none;
}
`);

entry.title: What Chinas economic troubles mean for the wold Economist ç»æµå­¦äººç²¾è¯»
entry.content:
æœ¬ç«™èƒŒæ™¯éŸ³ä¹å¯å·¦ä¸‹è§’æš‚åœ,ä¸‹æ–¹æ˜¯è¯¥ç¯‡æ–‡ç« çš„æœ—è¯»ç‰ˆéŸ³é¢‘,æœ‰éœ€æ±‚å¯ä»¥æ’­æ”¾(å¦‚æœä¸èƒ½æ˜¾ç¤º,å¯ä»¥ç‚¹å‡»é“¾æ¥:ç½‘æ˜“äº‘_Chinaâ€™s young want to work):

Only eight months ago Chinaâ€™s economy was expected to roar back to life. Zero-covid had been abandoned; the countryâ€™s shoppers and tourists allowed to roam free(è‡ªç”±èµ°åŠ¨). Yet the rebound has fizzled out(å¤±è´¥), with weak growth and deflation the result. This will not only affect its people. What happens in the worldâ€™s second-largest economy matters beyond its borders, too.

deflation the result

è¿™å¥è¯çš„ â€œdeflation the resultâ€ ç»“æ„åœ¨è‹±è¯­ä¸­ç¡®å®æœ‰äº›ä¸å¤ªå¸¸è§ã€‚åœ¨æ­£å¸¸çš„å¥å­ç»“æ„ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æœŸæœ›çœ‹åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªæ›´å®Œæ•´çš„å¥å‹ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ä½¿ç”¨ â€œisâ€ æˆ– â€œwasâ€ æ¥è¿æ¥ä¸»è¯­å’Œå®¾è¯­ã€‚

æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªæ›´åŠ æ ‡å‡†æˆ–æµç•…çš„è¯´æ³•åº”è¯¥æ˜¯ â€œdeflation is the resultâ€ æˆ– â€œdeflation was the resultâ€ã€‚

ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œæœ‰æ—¶å€™åœ¨æ–°é—»æŠ¥é“æˆ–æ–‡å­¦ä½œå“ä¸­ï¼Œä¸ºäº†å¼ºè°ƒæˆ–ä¸ºäº†é£æ ¼ï¼Œä½œè€…å¯èƒ½ä¼šä½¿ç”¨è¿™ç§çœç•¥ç»“æ„ã€‚ä¸è¿‡ï¼Œå¦‚æœæ˜¯æ­£å¼å†™ä½œæˆ–å­¦æœ¯è®ºæ–‡ï¼Œå»ºè®®ä½¿ç”¨å®Œæ•´çš„å¥å­ç»“æ„ã€‚

Because China is so big, its changing economic fortunes can drive overall global growth figures. But a slowing China also directly affects other countriesâ€™ prospects. Its households(å®¶åº­) and companies will buy fewer goods and services than they would have otherwise, with consequences for both the producers of these goods and other consumers of them. In some places, Chinaâ€™s difficulties will be a source of pain. In others, though, they will bring relief.

Commodity exporters (å•†å“å‡ºå£å•†)are especially exposed to Chinaâ€™s slowdown. The country guzzles(ç‹¼åè™å’½) almost a fifth of the worldâ€™s oil, half of its refined copper(ç²¾ç‚¼é“œ), nickel(é•) and zinc(é”Œ), and more than three-fifths of its iron ore(é“çŸ¿çŸ³). Chinaâ€™s property woes(æˆ¿åœ°äº§å±æœº) will mean it requires less of such supplies. That will be a knock for countries such as Zambia, where exports of copper and other metals to China amount to(å æ¯”è¾¾) 20% of gdp, and Australia, a big supplier of coal and iron. On August 22nd the boss of bhp(Broken Hill Proprietary Companyå¿…æ‹“), the worldâ€™s biggest miner, reported the lowest annual profit for the Australian firm in three years, and warned that Chinaâ€™s stimulus efforts were not producing changes on the ground.

Weak spots in the West include Germany. Faltering demand from China is one reason why the countryâ€™s economy has either contracted or stagnated over the past three quarters. And some Western companies are exposed through their reliance on China for revenues. In 2021 the 200 biggest multinationals in America, Europe and Japan made 13% of their sales in the country, earning $700bn. Tesla is more exposed still, making around a fifth of its sales in China; Qualcomm, a chipmaker, makes a staggering two-thirds.

Provided(åœ¨è¿™ç§èƒŒæ™¯ä¸‹) the slowdown does not escalate into a full-blown crisis(å…¨é¢å±æœº), the pain will remain relatively concentrated. Sales to China account for only 4-8% of business for all listed companies in America, Europe and Japan. Exports from America, Britain, France and Spain come to 1-2% of their respective outputs. Even in Germany, with an export share of nearly 4%, China would have to collapse in order to generate a sizeable hit to its economy.

è¿™äº›æ•°æ®æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆæ„æ€? ç›¸å¯¹è°æ¥è¯´?

è¿™äº›æ•°æ®æ˜¾ç¤ºäº†ä¸­å›½å¯¹å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶ç»æµçš„é‡è¦æ€§ï¼Œç‰¹åˆ«æ˜¯å¯¹é‚£äº›ä¸ä¸­å›½æœ‰è´¸æ˜“å…³ç³»çš„å›½å®¶ã€‚æ•°æ®æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†å¯¹æ¯”ä¸­å›½çš„ç»æµçŠ¶å†µå¯¹å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶å¯èƒ½äº§ç”Ÿçš„å½±å“ã€‚

Sales to China account for only 4-8% of business for all listed companies in America, Europe and Japan.
è¿™æ„å‘³ç€ï¼Œå¯¹äºç¾å›½ã€æ¬§æ´²å’Œæ—¥æœ¬çš„æ‰€æœ‰ä¸Šå¸‚å…¬å¸æ¥è¯´ï¼Œå…¶ä¸šåŠ¡ä¸­åªæœ‰4-8%æ˜¯é”€å¾€ä¸­å›½çš„ã€‚

Exports from America, Britain, France and Spain come to 1-2% of their respective outputs.
è¿™æ„å‘³ç€ï¼Œç¾å›½ã€è‹±å›½ã€æ³•å›½å’Œè¥¿ç­ç‰™å¯¹ä¸­å›½çš„å‡ºå£åªå å®ƒä»¬å„è‡ªæ€»äº§å€¼çš„1-2%ã€‚

Even in Germany, with an export share of nearly 4%, China would have to collapse in order to generate a sizeable hit to its economy.
è¿™æ„å‘³ç€ï¼Œå³ä½¿åœ¨å‡ºå£ä»½é¢æ¥è¿‘4%çš„å¾·å›½ï¼Œä¸­å›½çš„ç»æµä¹Ÿå¿…é¡»å´©æºƒæ‰èƒ½å¯¹å…¶ç»æµäº§ç”Ÿæ˜¾è‘—çš„æ‰“å‡»ã€‚

Sales to China account for only 4-8% of business for all listed companies in America, Europe and Japan. è¿™å¥è¯ä¸­listed companies æ˜¯æŒ‡?

â€œlisted companiesâ€ æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯åœ¨è‚¡ç¥¨äº¤æ˜“æ‰€ä¸Šå¸‚çš„å…¬å¸ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€è¿™äº›å…¬å¸çš„è‚¡ç¥¨åœ¨å…¬å¼€å¸‚åœºä¸Šå¯ä»¥ä¹°å–ã€‚åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œæåˆ°çš„æ˜¯ç¾å›½ã€æ¬§æ´²å’Œæ—¥æœ¬çš„ä¸Šå¸‚å…¬å¸ï¼Œè¯´æ˜è¿™äº›å…¬å¸çš„è‚¡ç¥¨å¯ä»¥åœ¨è¿™äº›åœ°åŒºçš„è‚¡ç¥¨äº¤æ˜“æ‰€ä¸Šè¿›è¡Œäº¤æ˜“ã€‚

Moreover, Chinaâ€™s struggles come at a time when the rest of the world is doing better than expected. In July the imf revised up(ä¸Šè°ƒ) its forecast for global growth, compared with projections in April. Most notable has been the rude health(å¼ºåŠ¿å¢é•¿) of the worldâ€™s biggest importer and Chinaâ€™s geopolitical rival, America, which some surveys suggest is growing at the red-hot pace of nearly 6%

When set against this backdrop(åœ¨è¿™ç§èƒŒæ™¯ä¸‹), Chinaâ€™s slowing growth should even provide a measure of relief for the worldâ€™s consumers, since it will mean less demand for commodities, bringing down prices and import costs. That in turn will ease the task faced by the Federal Reserve and other central banks. Many have already raised rates to their highest level in decades, and would not relish(ä¸å–œæ¬¢) having to go further still.

But what if things go badly wrong(ä¸¥é‡) in China? Under a worst-case scenario, a property meltdown could reverberate(æ³¢åŠ) through the worldâ€™s financial markets. A study published by the Bank of England in 2018 found that a â€œhard landingâ€ in China, where economic growth fell from 7% to -1%, would cause global asset prices to fall and rich-world currencies to rise as investors rushed in the direction of safer assets. Overall, British gdp would drop by 1.2%. Although most Western financial institutions have relatively little exposure to China, there are exceptions, such as hsbc and Standard Chartered, two British banks.

åœ¨2018å¹´è¿™ä¸ªç ”ç©¶å‡ºæ¥çš„æ—¶å€™, è¿™ä¸ªè¢«ç ”ç©¶çš„ä¸­å›½æƒ…å†µæ˜¯çœŸå®å­˜åœ¨, è¿˜æ˜¯å‡æƒ³çš„?

ä»æ‰€ç»™çš„ä¿¡æ¯æ¥çœ‹ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªç ”ç©¶æè¿°çš„æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªâ€œhard landingâ€æƒ…æ™¯ï¼Œå³ä¸­å›½çš„ç»æµå¢é•¿ä»7%è·Œè‡³-1%ã€‚è¿™ç§æè¿°å¬èµ·æ¥åƒæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå‡è®¾æˆ–æ¨¡æ‹Ÿçš„æƒ…å¢ƒï¼Œç”¨äºç ”ç©¶è¿™ç§æç«¯æƒ…å†µå¯¹å…¨çƒèµ„äº§ä»·æ ¼å’Œå…¶ä»–ç»æµæŒ‡æ ‡çš„å½±å“ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥æ¨æ–­è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå‡æƒ³çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯å½“æ—¶å®é™…å‘ç”Ÿçš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚

è¿™ä¸€æ®µä¸­çš„ç»æµç°è±¡æ€ä¹ˆç†è§£?

è¿™æ®µæè¿°äº†å¦‚æœä¸­å›½ç»å†äº†ä¸€ä¸ªâ€œç¡¬ç€é™†â€ï¼ˆå³ç»æµå¢é•¿è¿…é€Ÿä¸‹é™ï¼Œä»ç§¯æçš„å¢é•¿è½¬å˜ä¸ºè´Ÿå¢é•¿ï¼‰çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå¯èƒ½ä¼šå¯¹å…¨çƒç»æµäº§ç”Ÿå“ªäº›å½±å“ã€‚

å…¨çƒèµ„äº§ä»·æ ¼ä¸‹è·Œ: å½“ä¸­å›½è¿™æ ·ä¸€ä¸ªå·¨å¤§çš„ç»æµä½“ç»å†ä¸¥é‡çš„ç»æµè¡°é€€æ—¶ï¼Œè¿™ç§ä¸ç¡®å®šæ€§å’Œé£é™©ä¼šå¯¹å…¨çƒæŠ•èµ„è€…çš„ä¿¡å¿ƒäº§ç”Ÿå½±å“ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´å…¨çƒèµ„äº§ï¼ˆå¦‚è‚¡ç¥¨ã€æˆ¿åœ°äº§ç­‰ï¼‰çš„ä»·æ ¼ä¸‹è·Œã€‚

å¯Œè£•å›½å®¶çš„è´§å¸ä¸Šå‡: åœ¨ç»æµä¸ç¡®å®šæ€§å’Œé£é™©å¢åŠ çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼ŒæŠ•èµ„è€…é€šå¸¸ä¼šå¯»æ±‚æ›´ä¸ºå®‰å…¨çš„èµ„äº§æ¥ä¿æŠ¤å…¶è´¢å¯Œã€‚è¿™é€šå¸¸æ„å‘³ç€æŠ•èµ„äºè¢«è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯æ›´ä¸ºç¨³å¥å’Œå®‰å…¨çš„å›½å®¶çš„è´§å¸ï¼Œå¦‚ç¾å…ƒã€æ¬§å…ƒæˆ–æ—¥å…ƒã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œè¿™ç§è½¬ç§»ä¼šå¯¼è‡´è¿™äº›æ‰€è°“çš„â€œé¿é£æ¸¯â€è´§å¸çš„ä»·å€¼ä¸Šå‡ã€‚

è¿™äº›ç»æµç°è±¡çš„æè¿°åŸºäºæŠ•èµ„è€…å¯¹é£é™©çš„ååº”ã€‚åœ¨ç»æµä¸ç¡®å®šæ€§å’Œé£é™©å¢åŠ çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼ŒæŠ•èµ„è€…çš„è¡Œä¸ºæ¨¡å¼å¾€å¾€ä¼šå˜å¾—æ›´åŠ ä¿å®ˆï¼Œå¯»æ±‚å®‰å…¨çš„æŠ•èµ„æ–¹å¼ã€‚

A longer slowdown could lead China to turn inward, reducing its overseas investments and loans. Having become the worldâ€™s biggest bilateral creditor(åŒè¾¹å€ºæƒå›½) in 2017, it has already cut back as projects turn sour. Officials may become fussier still if they are firefighting at home. Observers will watch forthcoming celebrations of a decade of the â€œBelt and Road Initiativeâ€, the label under which China splurged(å¤§ä¸¾, æŒ¥éœ, å–å¼„) on bridges in Mozambique and ports in Pakistan, for signals of official intent(å®˜æ–¹æ„å›¾).

çŸ­è¯­

turn inward: è¿™ä¸ªçŸ­è¯­çš„æ„æ€æ˜¯ä¸­å›½å¯èƒ½ä¼šå˜å¾—æ›´åŠ å†…å‘ï¼Œå³ä¸“æ³¨äºå›½å†…çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯å›½å¤–çš„æ´»åŠ¨ã€‚åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œå®ƒæŒ‡çš„æ˜¯ä¸­å›½å¯èƒ½ä¼šå‡å°‘å¯¹å¤–æŠ•èµ„å’Œè´·æ¬¾ã€‚åŸæ„:å‘å†…è½¬å‘,æŒ‡ä¸€ä¸ªäººå¼€å§‹å…³æ³¨è‡ªå·±çš„å†…å¿ƒï¼Œåæ€è‡ªå·±çš„æƒ³æ³•å’Œæ„Ÿå—ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯å…³æ³¨å¤–éƒ¨ä¸–ç•Œã€‚

projects turn sour: â€œturn sourâ€ æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¹ è¯­ï¼Œæ„æ€æ˜¯æƒ…å†µå˜å¾—ä¸å¥½æˆ–å‡ºç°é—®é¢˜ã€‚åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œå®ƒæŒ‡çš„æ˜¯ä¸­å›½æŠ•èµ„çš„é¡¹ç›®æ²¡æœ‰è¾¾åˆ°é¢„æœŸçš„å›æŠ¥æˆ–å‡ºç°äº†é—®é¢˜ã€‚

Officials may become fussier still if they are firefighting at home: è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ¯”å–»ã€‚â€firefightingâ€ åœ¨è¿™é‡Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ¯”å–»ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºåº”å¯¹çªå‘æˆ–ç´§æ€¥æƒ…å†µã€‚å¥å­çš„æ„æ€æ˜¯ï¼Œå¦‚æœä¸­å›½å®˜å‘˜åœ¨å›½å†…å¿™äºåº”å¯¹å„ç§é—®é¢˜ï¼Œä»–ä»¬å¯èƒ½ä¼šå¯¹å›½å¤–çš„é¡¹ç›®å’ŒæŠ•èµ„å˜å¾—æ›´åŠ æŒ‘å‰”æˆ–å®¡æ…ã€‚

signals of official intent: è¿™æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯æ¥è‡ªä¸­å›½æ”¿åºœçš„å®˜æ–¹å£°æ˜æˆ–åŠ¨ä½œï¼Œå¯èƒ½æ˜¾ç¤ºå…¶æœªæ¥çš„ç­–ç•¥æˆ–è®¡åˆ’æ–¹å‘ã€‚

ç»æµå­¦æ¦‚å¿µ

bilateral creditor: â€œåŒè¾¹å€ºæƒå›½â€ã€‚â€Bilateralâ€ æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯æ¶‰åŠä¸¤ä¸ªå›½å®¶æˆ–ä¸¤ä¸ªå®ä½“çš„ã€‚åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œå½“æˆ‘ä»¬è¯´ä¸­å›½æˆä¸ºäº†ä¸–ç•Œä¸Šæœ€å¤§çš„åŒè¾¹å€ºæƒå›½ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€åœ¨ä¸å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶çš„åŒè¾¹å…³ç³»ä¸­ï¼Œä¸­å›½æ˜¯æœ€å¤§çš„å€ºæƒå›½ï¼Œå³æœ‰å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶æ¬ å…¶æœ€å¤šçš„å€ºåŠ¡ã€‚ä¸æ­¤ç›¸å…³çš„æ¦‚å¿µæœ‰:

åŒè¾¹å€ºåŠ¡: å½“ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å®¶ç›´æ¥å‘å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å®¶å€Ÿé’±æ—¶äº§ç”Ÿçš„å€ºåŠ¡ã€‚

å¤šè¾¹å€ºåŠ¡: å½“ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å®¶ä»å¤šå›½ç»„ç»‡ï¼ˆå¦‚å›½é™…è´§å¸åŸºé‡‘ç»„ç»‡æˆ–ä¸–ç•Œé“¶è¡Œï¼‰å€Ÿé’±æ—¶äº§ç”Ÿçš„å€ºåŠ¡ã€‚

å€ºæƒå›½: ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å®¶æˆ–å®ä½“æ‹¥æœ‰çš„å€ºåŠ¡çš„ä¸»è¦æŒæœ‰è€…æˆ–è´·æ–¹ã€‚

å€ºåŠ¡å›½: ä¸€ä¸ªå€Ÿé’±çš„å›½å®¶æˆ–å®ä½“ï¼Œå³å®ƒæ¬ å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶æˆ–å®ä½“çš„é’±ã€‚

å…¬å…±å€ºåŠ¡: è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å®¶çš„æ”¿åºœå¯¹å…¶å›½å†…å’Œå¤–éƒ¨å€ºæƒäººæ¬ æ¬¾çš„æ€»é¢ã€‚å³, ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å®¶æ”¿åºœæ¬ å…¶å›½å†…å¤–æ‰€æœ‰å€ºæƒäººçš„æ€»é¢ã€‚è¿™åŒ…æ‹¬æ¬ æœ¬å›½å…¬æ°‘ã€ä¼ä¸šã€å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶æˆ–å›½é™…æœºæ„çš„å€ºåŠ¡ã€‚å…¬å…±å€ºåŠ¡å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡å‘è¡Œå›½å€ºã€çŸ­æœŸç¥¨æ®æˆ–ä»å›½é™…æœºæ„è·å¾—è´·æ¬¾ç­‰æ–¹å¼äº§ç”Ÿã€‚ç¾å›½çš„å…¬å…±å€ºåŠ¡æ˜¯ä¸–ç•Œä¸Šæœ€å¤§çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒå€Ÿå…¥äº†å¤§é‡èµ„é‡‘æ¥æ»¡è¶³å…¶é¢„ç®—èµ¤å­—å’Œèµ„é‡‘éœ€æ±‚ã€‚

å¤–éƒ¨å€ºåŠ¡: è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å®¶æˆ–å…¶å…¬æ°‘æ¬ å¤–éƒ¨å€ºæƒäººçš„æ€»é¢ã€‚å³, è¿™æ˜¯æŒ‡ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å®¶æˆ–å…¶å…¬æ°‘æ¬ å¤–éƒ¨å€ºæƒäººçš„æ€»é¢ã€‚è¿™åŒ…æ‹¬æ¬ å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶ã€å¤–å›½ä¼ä¸šæˆ–å›½é™…é‡‘èæœºæ„çš„å€ºåŠ¡ã€‚å¤–éƒ¨å€ºåŠ¡åªå…³æ³¨ä¸å¤–éƒ¨ä¸–ç•Œçš„é‡‘èå…³ç³»ï¼Œä¸åŒ…æ‹¬å›½å†…çš„å€ºåŠ¡ã€‚ä¸­å›½å·²ç»æˆä¸ºæœ€å¤§çš„åŒè¾¹å€ºæƒå›½ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€åœ¨ä¸å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶çš„åŒè¾¹å…³ç³»ä¸­ï¼Œä¸­å›½æ˜¯ä¸»è¦çš„è´·æ–¹ã€‚

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦å€Ÿé’±?:
å³ä½¿å¤§çš„ç»æµä½“ï¼Œå¦‚ä¸­å›½ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½ä¼šé€‰æ‹©å€Ÿé’±ã€‚åŸå› æœ‰å¾ˆå¤šï¼š
åˆºæ¿€ç»æµå¢é•¿: å€Ÿæ¬¾å¯ä»¥ç”¨äºåŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½é¡¹ç›®å’Œå…¶ä»–æŠ•èµ„ï¼Œå¸®åŠ©åˆºæ¿€ç»æµå¢é•¿ã€‚
å¹³è¡¡é¢„ç®—èµ¤å­—: å½“æ”¿åºœçš„æ”¯å‡ºè¶…è¿‡å…¶æ”¶å…¥æ—¶ï¼Œå€Ÿæ¬¾å¯ä»¥å¸®åŠ©å¡«è¡¥å·®è·ã€‚
åˆ©ç”¨ä½åˆ©ç‡: åœ¨å…¨çƒåˆ©ç‡è¾ƒä½æ—¶ï¼Œå€Ÿæ¬¾æˆæœ¬å¯èƒ½ä¼šè¾ƒä½ã€‚è¿™ä¸ºå›½å®¶æä¾›äº†ç­¹èµ„çš„æœºä¼šï¼Œç”¨äºé•¿æœŸæŠ•èµ„ã€‚
å¤–äº¤å’Œæˆ˜ç•¥ç›®çš„: å¦‚â€œä¸€å¸¦ä¸€è·¯â€è¿™æ ·çš„é¡¹ç›®ï¼Œé™¤äº†ç»æµç›®çš„å¤–ï¼Œè¿˜å¯èƒ½æœ‰å¤–äº¤å’Œæˆ˜ç•¥ç›®çš„ã€‚

ME:
ä»ä½ åˆšåˆšçš„å›ç­”æ¥çœ‹, ä½ çš„æ„æ€æ˜¯, ç¾å›½å–„äºå‘åˆ«äººå€Ÿé’±è¿‡æ¥, ä¸­å›½åè€Œå–œæ¬¢ç»™åˆ«äººæ”¾è´·? å’‹æ„Ÿè§‰è¿™å’Œç»æµä½“é‡å¯¹ä¸ä¸Šå·å‘¢?
GPT:
å…³äºç¾å›½å’Œä¸­å›½çš„å€ºæƒå’Œå€ºåŠ¡å…³ç³»ï¼š

æ˜¯çš„ï¼Œä»æŸç§æ„ä¹‰ä¸Šè®²ï¼Œæ‚¨çš„æ€»ç»“æ˜¯å‡†ç¡®çš„ã€‚ä½†è¿™å¹¶ä¸æ„å‘³ç€ç¾å›½åªä¼šå€Ÿé’±ï¼Œè€Œä¸­å›½åªä¼šæ”¾è´·ã€‚ä¸¤å›½éƒ½æœ‰è´·æ¬¾å’Œå€Ÿæ¬¾çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œä½†å…³é”®åœ¨äºè§„æ¨¡å’Œç›®çš„ã€‚

ç¾å›½ï¼šç¾å›½ç»å¸¸æœ‰é¢„ç®—èµ¤å­—ï¼Œéœ€è¦å‘è¡Œå›½å€ºæ¥ç­¹é›†èµ„é‡‘ã€‚ç”±äºç¾å…ƒæ˜¯å›½é™…å‚¨å¤‡è´§å¸å’Œå…¨çƒè´¸æ˜“çš„ä¸»è¦ç»“ç®—è´§å¸ï¼Œå…¨çƒå¯¹ç¾å›½å›½å€ºçš„éœ€æ±‚éå¸¸å¤§ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œç¾å›½èƒ½å¤Ÿä»¥æä½çš„åˆ©ç‡å€Ÿå…¥å¤§é‡èµ„é‡‘ã€‚è¿™äº›èµ„é‡‘ç”¨äºæ”¯æŒç¾å›½çš„å…¬å…±æ”¯å‡ºï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬å†›äº‹ã€ç¤¾ä¼šç¦åˆ©ã€åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½ç­‰ã€‚

ä¸­å›½ï¼šè¿‡å»å‡ åå¹´ï¼Œä¸­å›½ç»æµè¿…é€Ÿå¢é•¿ï¼Œç´¯ç§¯äº†å¤§é‡å¤–æ±‡å‚¨å¤‡ã€‚ä¸­å›½é€‰æ‹©ä½¿ç”¨éƒ¨åˆ†å‚¨å¤‡è¿›è¡Œæµ·å¤–æŠ•èµ„ï¼Œå°¤å…¶æ˜¯åœ¨åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½å’Œèƒ½æºé¢†åŸŸã€‚è¿™ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆä¸­å›½åœ¨â€œä¸€å¸¦ä¸€è·¯â€é¡¹ç›®ä¸­ï¼Œä¸è®¸å¤šå›½å®¶å»ºç«‹äº†è´·æ¬¾å’ŒæŠ•èµ„å…³ç³»ã€‚

ä»ç»æµä½“é‡æ¥çœ‹ï¼Œç¾å›½å’Œä¸­å›½éƒ½æ˜¯å…¨çƒæœ€å¤§çš„ç»æµä½“ï¼Œä½†ä¸¤å›½çš„ç»æµç»“æ„ã€å‘å±•é˜¶æ®µå’Œç­–ç•¥æœ‰æ‰€ä¸åŒï¼Œè¿™å¯¼è‡´äº†ä»–ä»¬åœ¨å…¨çƒé‡‘èå¸‚åœºä¸Šçš„è§’è‰²å’Œè¡Œä¸ºä¹Ÿæœ‰æ‰€å·®å¼‚ã€‚

Real difficulties at home would also change how the world perceives China. Rapid growth, along with generous overseas lending, boosted the countryâ€™s reputation. According to a recent survey of two dozen countries(12 * 2 = 24 ä¸ªå›½å®¶) by Pew, a pollster(æ°‘æ„è°ƒæŸ¥æœºæ„), people in rich locations had a generally unfavourable view(è´Ÿé¢çœ‹æ³•) of China. The picture was different in much of the emerging world(æ–°å…´å›½å®¶): Mexicans, Kenyans, Nigerians and South Africans all saw China in a more favourable light, and welcomed Chinese investment. The question is whether that will still be true in a yearâ€™s time(æƒ…å†µæ˜¯å¦ä¾ç„¶å¦‚æ­¤). â–

entry.title: How to Do Great Work
entry.content:
>æœªå®Œå¾…ç»­>
ä»æ¨ä¸Šçœ‹åˆ°æœ‰äººæåŠ›åˆ†äº«è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« ,é‚æ‰¾æ¥è¯»è¯»:é˜…è¯»åŸæ–‡è¯·ç‚¹å‡»æˆ‘

æœ¬ç¯‡é‡‡ç”¨äº†ç²—è¯»+gptæ®µå¼æ€»ç»“.

How to Do Great Work

July 2023

If you collected lists of techniques for doing great work in a lot of different fields, what would the intersection look like? I decided to find out by making it.

Partly my goal was to create a guide that could be used by someone working in any field. But I was also curious about the shape of the intersection. And one thing this exercise shows is that it does have a definite shape; itâ€™s not just a point labelled â€œwork hard.â€

The following recipe assumes youâ€™re very ambitious.

â€œä»¥ä¸‹çš„å»ºè®®æ˜¯ä¸ºé‚£äº›éå¸¸æœ‰é‡å¿ƒçš„äººå‡†å¤‡çš„ã€‚â€

Part 1 ä»¥å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå¯èˆª, ç”¨åŠªåŠ›å¼€åˆ›æ–°ä¸–ç•Œã€‚ğŸš€

Part 1 å†…å®¹

The first step is to decide what to work on. The work you choose needs to have three qualities: it has to be something you have a natural aptitude for, that you have a deep interest in, and that offers scope to do great work.

å®ƒå¿…é¡»æ˜¯ä½ å¤©ç”Ÿæ“…é•¿çš„ã€ä½ æ·±æ„Ÿå…´è¶£çš„ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æœ‰æ½œåŠ›åšå¾—å‡ºè‰²çš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚

In practice you donâ€™t have to worry much about the third criterion. Ambitious people are if anything already too conservative about it. So all you need to do is find something you have an aptitude for and great interest in. [1]

[1]

I donâ€™t think you could give a precise definition of what counts as great work. Doing great work means doing something important so well that you expand peopleâ€™s ideas of whatâ€™s possible. But thereâ€™s no threshold for importance. Itâ€™s a matter of degree, and often hard to judge at the time anyway. So Iâ€™d rather people focused on developing their interests rather than worrying about whether theyâ€™re important or not. Just try to do something amazing, and leave it to future generations to say if you succeeded.
æˆ‘ä¸è®¤ä¸ºä½ å¯ä»¥ç»™å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªç²¾ç¡®çš„å®šä¹‰ï¼Œä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯ä¼Ÿå¤§çš„å·¥ä½œã€‚åšä¸€ä»¶ä¼Ÿå¤§çš„å·¥ä½œæ„å‘³ç€æŠŠé‡è¦çš„äº‹æƒ…åšå¾—å¾ˆå¥½ï¼Œä»è€Œæ‹“å±•äº†äººä»¬å¯¹å¯èƒ½æ€§çš„çœ‹æ³•ã€‚ä½†é‡è¦æ€§å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰ç•Œé™ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç¨‹åº¦é—®é¢˜ï¼Œè€Œä¸”é€šå¸¸å¾ˆéš¾åœ¨å½“æ—¶åšå‡ºåˆ¤æ–­ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘å®æ„¿äººä»¬ä¸“æ³¨äºå‘å±•ä»–ä»¬çš„å…´è¶£ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯æ‹…å¿ƒä»–ä»¬æ˜¯å¦é‡è¦ã€‚è¯•ç€å»åšä¸€äº›ä»¤äººæƒŠå¹çš„äº‹æƒ…ï¼Œå¦‚æœä½ æˆåŠŸäº†ï¼Œç•™ç»™åä»£å»è¯´ã€‚

That sounds straightforward, but itâ€™s often quite difficult. When youâ€™re young you donâ€™t know what youâ€™re good at or what different kinds of work are like. Some kinds of work you end up doing may not even exist yet. So while some people know what they want to do at 14, most have to figure it out.

The way to figure out what to work on is by working. If youâ€™re not sure what to work on, guess. But pick something and get going. Youâ€™ll probably guess wrong some of the time, but thatâ€™s fine. It's good to know about multiple things; some of the biggest discoveries come from noticing connections between different fields.

Develop a habit of working on your own projects. Donâ€™t let â€œworkâ€ mean something other people tell you to do. If you do manage to do great work one day, it will probably be on a project of your own. It may be within some bigger project, but youâ€™ll be driving your part of it.

What should your projects be? Whatever seems to you excitingly ambitious. As you grow older and your taste in projects evolves, exciting and important will converge. At 7 it may seem excitingly ambitious to build huge things out of Lego, then at 14 to teach yourself calculus, till at 21 youâ€™re starting to explore unanswered questions in physics. But always preserve excitingness.

Thereâ€™s a kind of excited curiosity thatâ€™s both the engine and the rudder of great work. It will not only drive you, but if you let it have its way, will also show you what to work on.

What are you excessively curious about â€” curious to a degree that would bore most other people? Thatâ€™s what youâ€™re looking for.

Once youâ€™ve found something youâ€™re excessively interested in, the next step is to learn enough about it to get you to one of the frontiers of knowledge. Knowledge expands fractally(åˆ†å½¢), and from a distance its edges look smooth, but once you learn enough to get close to one, they turn out to be full of gaps.

fractal
åˆ†å½¢æ˜¯ä¸€ç§åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªå°ºåº¦ä¸Šéƒ½é‡å¤ç›¸åŒæˆ–ç›¸ä¼¼æ¨¡å¼çš„ç»“æ„ã€‚è¿™æ„å‘³ç€çŸ¥è¯†çš„å¢é•¿æ˜¯å±‚å±‚å å ã€æ— ç©·å°½çš„ï¼Œå½“ä½ æ·±å…¥ä¸€ä¸ªä¸»é¢˜ï¼Œä½ ä¼šå‘ç°æ›´å¤šçš„å­ä¸»é¢˜å’Œæ›´ç»†èŠ‚çš„çŸ¥è¯†ã€‚

The next step is to notice them. This takes some skill, because your brain wants to ignore such gaps in order to make a simpler model of the world. Many discoveries have come from asking questions about things that everyone else took for granted. [2]

[2]

A lot of standup comedy is based on noticing anomalies in everyday life. â€œDid you ever noticeâ€¦?â€ New ideas come from doing this about nontrivial things. Which may help explain why peopleâ€™s reaction to a new idea is often the first half of laughing: Ha!
æˆ‘æ“!ä½ è¯´åˆ°è¿™ä¸ªæˆ‘å¯ä¸å›°äº†å•Š! Lets Welcome Louis CK, Bill Burr and Anthony Jeselnik!

If the answers seem strange, so much the better(å²‚ä¸æ˜¯æ›´å¥½). Great work often has a tincture of strangeness. You see this from painting to math. It would be affected to try to manufacture it, but if it appears, embrace it.

å°è¯•äººä¸ºåˆ¶é€ è¿™ç§æ„Ÿè§‰å¯èƒ½ä¼šæ˜¾å¾—åšä½œï¼Œä½†å¦‚æœå®ƒè‡ªç„¶å‡ºç°ï¼Œå°±æ‹¥æŠ±å®ƒå§ã€‚

Boldly chase outlier(ä¸ä¼—ä¸åŒ) ideas, even if other people arenâ€™t interested in them â€” in fact, especially if they arenâ€™t. If youâ€™re excited about some possibility that everyone else ignores, and you have enough expertise to say precisely what theyâ€™re all overlooking, thatâ€™s as good a bet as(æœ€å¥½çš„æœºä¼š) youâ€™ll find. [3]

[3]

That second qualifier is critical. If youâ€™re excited about something most authorities discount, but you canâ€™t give a more precise explanation than â€œthey donâ€™t get it,â€ then youâ€™re starting to drift into the territory of cranks.

å°å¿ƒè¿›å…¥â€æ€ªäººâ€(æ°‘ç§‘/è¿›å…¥éä¸»æµç§‘å­¦çš„é¢†åŸŸ)çš„åœˆå­!

Four steps: choose a field, learn enough to get to the frontier, notice gaps, explore promising ones. This is how practically everyone whoâ€™s done great work has done it, from painters to physicists.

Steps two and four will require hard work. It may not be possible to prove that you have to work hard to do great things, but the empirical(ç»éªŒä¸»ä¹‰çš„) evidence is on the scale of the evidence for mortality. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s essential to work on something youâ€™re deeply interested in. Interest will drive you to work harder than mere diligence ever could.

but the empirical evidence is on the scale of the evidence for mortality

The three most powerful motives are curiosity, delight, and the desire to do something impressive. Sometimes they converge, and that combination is the most powerful of all.

The big prize is to discover a new fractal bud. You notice a crack in the surface of knowledge, pry it open, and thereâ€™s a whole world inside.

Part 2 å†…å®¹

Letâ€™s talk a little more about the complicated business of figuring out what to work on. The main reason itâ€™s hard is that you canâ€™t tell what most kinds of work are like except by doing them. Which means the four steps overlap: you may have to work at something for years before you know how much you like it or how good you are at it. And in the meantime youâ€™re not doing, and thus not learning about, most other kinds of work. So in the worst case you choose late based on very incomplete information. [4]

(and also very little progress under the worst situation)

[4]

Finding something to work on is not simply a matter of finding a match between the current version of you and a list of known problems. Youâ€™ll often have to coevolve with the problem. Thatâ€™s why it can sometimes be so hard to figure out what to work on. The search space is huge. Itâ€™s the cartesian product of all possible types of work, both known and yet to be discovered, and all possible future versions of you.

The nature of ambition exacerbates this problem. Ambition comes in two forms, one that precedes interest in the subject and one that grows out of it. Most people who do great work have a mix, and the more you have of the former, the harder it will be to decide what to do.

What should you do if youâ€™re young and ambitious but donâ€™t know what to work on? What you should not do is drift along passively, assuming the problem will solve itself. You need to take action. But there is no systematic procedure you can follow. When you read biographies of people whoâ€™ve done great work, itâ€™s remarkable how much luck is involved. They discover what to work on as a result of a chance meeting, or by reading a book they happen to pick up. So you need to make yourself a big target for luck, and the way to do that is to be curious. Try lots of things, meet lots of people, read lots of books, ask lots of questions. [5]

[5]

There are many reasons curious people are more likely to do great work, but one of the more subtle is that, by casting a wide net, theyâ€™re more likely to find the right thing to work on in the first place.

When in doubt, optimize(ä¼˜å…ˆ) for interestingness. Fields change as you learn more about them. What mathematicians do, for example, is very different from what you do in high school math classes. So you need to give different types of work a chance to show you what they're like. But a field should become increasingly interesting as you learn more about it. If it doesn't, it's probably not for you.

Donâ€™t worry if you find youâ€™re interested in different things than other people. The stranger your tastes in interestingness, the better. Strange tastes are often strong ones, and a strong taste for work means youâ€™ll be productive. And youâ€™re more likely to find new things if youâ€™re looking where few have looked before.

ä¸è¦æ‹…å¿ƒå…´è¶£åé—¨

One sign that youâ€™re suited for some kind of work is when you like even the parts that other people find tedious(ä¹å‘³) or frightening.

But fields arenâ€™t people; you donâ€™t owe them any loyalty. If in the course of working on one thing you discover another thatâ€™s more exciting, donâ€™t be afraid to switch.

ä½ ä¸æ¬ å®ƒä»¬ä»»ä½•å¿ è¯šã€‚

If youâ€™re making something for people, make sure itâ€™s something they actually want. The best way to do this is to make something you yourself want. Write the story you want to read; build the tool you want to use. Since your friends probably have similar interests, this will also get you your initial audience(åˆæ­¥å—ä¼—).

This should follow from the excitingness rule. Obviously the most exciting story to write will be the one you want to read. The reason I mention this case explicitly is that so many people get it wrong. Instead of making what they want, they try to make what some imaginary, more sophisticated audience wants. And once you go down that route, youâ€™re lost. [6]

[6]

It can also be dangerous to make things for an audience you feel is less sophisticated than you, if that causes you to talk down to them. You can make a lot of money doing that, if you do it in a sufficiently cynical way, but itâ€™s not the route to great work. Not that anyone using this m.o. would care.

Even when youâ€™ve found something exciting to work on, working on it is not always straightforward. There will be times when some new idea makes you leap out of bed in the morning and get straight to work. But there will also be plenty of times when things aren't like that.

You donâ€™t just put out your sail and get blown forward by inspiration. There are headwinds and currents and hidden shoals. So thereâ€™s a technique to working, just as there is one to sailing.

For example, while you must work hard, itâ€™s possible to work too hard, and if you do that youâ€™ll find you get diminishing returns: fatigue will make you stupid, and eventually even damage your health. The point at which work yields diminishing returns depends on the type. Some of the hardest types you might only be able to do for four or five hours a day.

It will probably be harder to start working than to keep working. Youâ€™ll often have to trick yourself to get over that initial threshold(é—¨æ§›). Donâ€™t worry about this; itâ€™s the nature of work, not a flaw in your character. Work has a sort of activation energy, both per day and per project. And since this threshold is fake in the sense that itâ€™s higher than the energy required to keep going, itâ€™s ok to tell yourself a lie of corresponding magnitude to get over it.

â€œThough lying to yourself is usually detrimental to producing great work, there are rare instances where it can be beneficial. Hereâ€™s an example.â€
â€œLying to yourself typically hinders great work. However, in some rare cases, like the one Iâ€™m about to describe, it doesnâ€™t.â€

Similar techniques work for starting new projects. Itâ€™s ok to lie to yourself about how much work a project will entail(éœ€è¦), for example. Lots of great things began with someone saying "How hard could it be?"

This is one case where the young have an advantage. Theyâ€™re more optimistic, and even though one of the sources of their optimism is ignorance(ä»–ä»¬çš„ä¹è§‚æ¥æºäºæ— çŸ¥), in this case ignorance can sometimes beat knowledge(æ— çŸ¥æœ‰æ—¶ç”šè‡³å¯ä»¥æ‰“è´¥çŸ¥è¯†).

Try to finish what you start, though, even if it turns out to be more work than you expected. Finishing things is not just an exercise in tidiness or self-discipline. In many projects a lot of the best work happens in what was meant to be the final stage.

æ—¢ç„¶å¼€å§‹äº†,å°±åšä¸‹å»å§!

Another permissible lie is to exaggerate the importance of what you're working on, at least in your own mind. If that helps you discover something new, it may turn out not to have been a lie after all. [7]

[7]

This idea I learned from Hardyâ€™s A Mathematicianâ€™s Apology, which I recommend to anyone ambitious to do great work, in any field.

Since there are two senses of starting work â€” per day and per project â€” there are also two forms of procrastination(æ‹–å»¶). Per-project procrastination is far the more dangerous. You put off starting that ambitious project from year to year because the time isnâ€™t quite right. When youâ€™re procrastinating in units of years, you can get a lot not done. [8]

ç›¸æ¯”äºæ¯æ—¥å¼€å§‹åšäº‹çš„æ‹–å»¶,é¡¹ç›®çš„æ‹–å»¶æ›´åŠ ä¸¥é‡å’Œå¯æ€•!(å› ä¸ºåªè¦ä¸å¼€å§‹å°±æ°¸è¿œä¹Ÿä¸ä¼šå¼€å§‹â€¦)

[8]

Just as we overestimate what we can do in a day and underestimate what we can do over several years, we overestimate the damage done by procrastinating for a day and underestimate the damage done by procrastinating for several years.

One reason per-project procrastination is so dangerous is that it usually camouflages itself as work. Youâ€™re not just sitting around doing nothing; youâ€™re working industriously on something else. So per-project procrastination doesnâ€™t set off the alarms that per-day procrastination does. Youâ€™re too busy to notice it.

é¡¹ç›®çš„æ‹–å»¶ä¸ä¼šæ˜¾æ€§åœ°æé†’ä½ !æ‰€ä»¥å®ƒä¼šä¼ªè£…!

The way to beat it is to stop occasionally and ask yourself: â€œAm I working on what I most want to work on?â€. When youâ€™re young itâ€™s ok if the answer is sometimes no, but this gets increasingly dangerous as you get older. [9]

[9]

[9] You canâ€™t usually get paid for doing exactly what you want, especially early on. There are two options: get paid for doing work close to what you want and hope to push it closer, or get paid for doing something else entirely and do your own projects on the side. Both can work, but both have drawbacks: in the first approach your work is compromised by default, and in the second you have to fight to get time to do it.

Great work usually entails spending what would seem to most people an unreasonable amount of time on a problem. You can't think of this time as a cost, or it will seem too high. You have to find the work sufficiently engaging as itâ€™s happening.

æ—¶é—´æ˜¯åªä¸ªç¤¾äº¤è§‚å¿µ:æ—¶é—´è§‚

There may be some jobs where you have to work diligently for years at things you hate before you get to the good part, but this is not how great work happens. Great work happens by focusing consistently on something youâ€™re genuinely interested in. When you pause to take stock, youâ€™re surprised how far youâ€™ve come.

The reason weâ€™re surprised is that we underestimate the cumulative effect(ç´¯ç§¯æ•ˆåº”) of work. Writing a page a day doesnâ€™t sound like much, but if you do it every day youâ€™ll write a book a year. Thatâ€™s the key: consistency. People who do great things don't get a lot done every day. They get something done, rather than nothing.

ç¡®ä¿äº§å‡º!

If you do work that compounds, youâ€™ll get exponential(æŒ‡æ•°çº§çš„) growth. Most people who do this do it unconsciously, but itâ€™s worth stopping to think about. Learning, for example, is an instance of this phenomenon: the more you learn about something, the easier it is to learn more. Growing an audience is another: the more fans you have, the more new fans they'll bring you.

The trouble with exponential growth is that the curve feels flat in the beginning. It isnâ€™t; itâ€™s still a wonderful exponential curve. But we canâ€™t grasp that intuitively(ç›´è§‰åœ°), so we underrate exponential growth in its early stages.

å¼€å§‹æ…¢çœŸçš„ä¸è¦ç´§!

Something that grows exponentially can become so valuable that itâ€™s worth making an extraordinary effort to get it started. But since we underrate exponential growth early on, this too is mostly done unconsciously: people push through(ä»˜å‡ºé¢å¤–çš„åŠªåŠ›) the initial, unrewarding phase of learning something new because they know from experience that learning new things always takes an initial push, or they grow their audience one fan at a time because they have nothing better to do. If people consciously realized they could invest in exponential growth, many more would do it.

Work doesnâ€™t just happen when youâ€™re trying to. Thereâ€™s a kind of undirected thinking (æ— ç›®çš„çš„æ€è€ƒ)you do when walking or taking a shower or lying in bed that can be very powerful. By letting your mind wander a little, youâ€™ll often solve problems you were unable to solve by frontal attack.

You have to be working hard in the normal way to benefit from this phenomenon, though. You canâ€™t just walk around daydreaming. The daydreaming has to be interleaved with(äº¤ç»‡åœ¨ä¸€èµ·) deliberate work that feeds it questions. [10]

[10]

If you set your life up right, it will deliver the focus-relax cycle automatically. The perfect setup is an office you work in and that you walk to and from.

æå‰å®‰æ’å¥½å·¥ä½œå¾ˆé‡è¦!

Everyone knows to avoid distractions at work, but itâ€™s also important to avoid them in the other half of the cycle. When you let your mind wander, it wanders to whatever you care about most at that moment. So avoid the kind of distraction that pushes your work out of the top spot, or youâ€™ll waste this valuable type of thinking on the distraction instead. (Exception: Donâ€™t avoid love.)

Consciously cultivate your taste in the work done in your field. Until you know which is the best and what makes it so, you don't know what you're aiming for.

åœ¨å“å‘³æ–¹é¢,è¿½æ±‚å“è¶Š

And that is what youâ€™re aiming for, because if you donâ€™t try to be the best, you wonâ€™t even be good. This observation has been made by so many people in so many different fields that it might be worth thinking about why itâ€™s true. It could be because ambition is a phenomenon where almost all the error is in one direction â€” where almost all the shells that miss the target miss by falling short. Or it could be because ambition to be the best is a qualitatively different thing from ambition to be good. Or maybe being good is simply too vague a standard. Probably all three are true. [11]

There may be some very unworldly people who do great work without consciously trying to. If you want to expand this rule to cover that case, it becomes: Donâ€™t try to be anything except the best.

Fortunately thereâ€™s a kind of economy of scale here. Though it might seem like youâ€™d be taking on a heavy burden by trying to be the best, in practice you often end up net ahead(è·ç›Š). Itâ€™s exciting, and also strangely liberating(å¥‡å¦™çš„è§£æ”¾). It simplifies things. In some ways itâ€™s easier to try to be the best one than to try merely to be good one.

One way to aim high is to try to make something that people will care about in a hundred years. Not because their opinions matter more than your contemporariesâ€™, but because something that still seems good in a hundred years is more likely to be genuinely good.

Donâ€™t try to work in a distinctive style. Just try to do the best job you can; you wonâ€™t be able to help doing it in a distinctive way.

Style is doing things in a distinctive way without trying to. Trying to is affectation(åšä½œ).

Affectation is in effect to pretend that someone other than you is doing the work. You adopt an impressive but fake persona(ä¼ªè£…), and while youâ€™re pleased with the impressiveness, the fakeness is what shows in the work. [12]

[12]

This gets more complicated in work like acting, where the goal is to adopt a fake persona. But even here itâ€™s possible to be affected. Perhaps the rule in such fields should be to avoid unintentional affectation.

The temptation to be someone else is greatest for the young. They often feel like nobodies. But you never need to worry about that problem, because itâ€™s self-solving if you work on sufficiently ambitious projects. If you succeed at an ambitious project, youâ€™re not a nobody; youâ€™re the person who did it. So just do the work and your identity will take care of itself.

â€œAvoid affectationâ€ is a useful rule so far as it goes, but how would you express this idea positively? How would you say what to be, instead of what not to be? The best answer is earnest. If youâ€™re earnest you avoid not just affectation but a whole set of similar vices.

earnest

æˆ‘ç†è§£:æ‰¾åˆ°æœ¬æˆ‘.åªåšè‡ªå·±.
åªæ˜¯è¿«äºå„ç§åŸå› , äººä»¬è¦ä¹ˆä¸€è¾ˆå­ä¹Ÿæ‰¾ä¸åˆ°, è¦ä¹ˆå°±ç®—æ‰¾åˆ°äº†ä¹Ÿæ²¡ä»€ä¹ˆæœºä¼šåšè‡ªå·±. ç‰¹åˆ«æ˜¯åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªäº’å®³,äº’å·çš„ç¤¾ä¼š,æƒ³å•¥å‘¢,åšæ¢¦.

The core of being earnest is being intellectually honest(å¿ƒæ™ºçš„åŸå¸‚). Weâ€™re taught as children to be honest as an unselfish virtue â€” as a kind of sacrifice. But in fact itâ€™s a source of power too. To see new ideas, you need an exceptionally sharp eye for the truth. Youâ€™re trying to see more truth than others have seen so far. And how can you have a sharp eye for the truth if youâ€™re intellectually dishonest?

å¿ƒæ™ºè¯šå®æ˜¯æœ‰æ•é”çš„æ´å¯ŸåŠ›çš„å‰æ.

One way to avoid intellectual dishonesty is to maintain a slight positive pressure in the opposite direction. Be aggressively willing to admit that you're mistaken. Once youâ€™ve admitted you were mistaken about something, youâ€™re free. Till then you have to carry it. [13]

Another more subtle component of earnestness is informality. Informality is much more important than its grammatically negative name implies. Itâ€™s not merely the absence of something. It means focusing on what matters instead of what doesnâ€™t.

What formality and affectation have in common is that as well as doing the work, youâ€™re trying to seem a certain way as youâ€™re doing it. But any energy that goes into how you seem comes out of being good(ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œç”¨åœ¨ä½ çš„å¤–è§‚ä¸Šçš„ä»»ä½•èƒ½é‡éƒ½ä¼šå‡å°‘ä½ çš„å®é™…èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚). Thatâ€™s one reason nerds have an advantage in doing great work: they expend little effort on seeming anything. In fact thatâ€™s basically the definition of a nerd.

Nerds have a kind of innocent boldness thatâ€™s exactly what you need in doing great work. Itâ€™s not learned(ä¸æ˜¯åå¤©ä¹ å¾—çš„); itâ€™s preserved from childhood. So hold onto it. Be the one who puts things out there rather than the one who sits back and offers sophisticated-sounding criticisms of them(æŒ‡ä»£nerds æå‡ºçš„ things). â€œItâ€™s easy to criticizeâ€ is true in the most literal sense, and the route to great work is never easy.

There may be some jobs where itâ€™s an advantage to be cynical and pessimistic, but if you want to do great work itâ€™s an advantage to be optimistic, even though that means youâ€™ll risk looking like a fool sometimes. Thereâ€™s an old tradition of doing the opposite. The Old Testament says itâ€™s better to keep quiet lest you look like a fool. But thatâ€™s advice for seeming smart. If you actually want to discover new things, it's better to take the risk of telling people your ideas.(make your ideas known.)

Some people are naturally earnest, and with others it takes a conscious effort(éœ€è¦åˆ»æ„åŠªåŠ›). Either kind of earnestness will suffice. But I doubt it would be possible to do great work without being earnest. Itâ€™s so hard to do even if you are. You don't have enough margin for error to accommodate the distortions introduced by being affected, intellectually dishonest, orthodox, fashionable, or cool. [14]

to accommodate the distortionsï¼šæ¥å®¹çº³æˆ–å®¹å¿é‚£äº›æ‰­æ›²æˆ–è¯¯å¯¼ã€‚â€distortionsâ€åœ¨è¿™é‡ŒæŒ‡çš„æ˜¯ç”±äºé”™è¯¯è§‚å¿µæˆ–æ€åº¦å¯¼è‡´çš„åå·®æˆ–è¯¯å¯¼ã€‚

introduced by being affectedï¼šå—åˆ°åšä½œçš„å½±å“æ‰€å¼•å…¥çš„ã€‚â€affectedâ€åœ¨è¿™é‡ŒæŒ‡çš„æ˜¯åšä½œçš„ã€ä¸çœŸå®çš„ã€‚

Great work is consistent not only with who did it, but with itself. Itâ€™s usually all of a piece. So if you face a decision in the middle of working on something, ask which choice is more consistent.

You may have to throw things away and redo them. You wonâ€™t necessarily have to, but you have to be willing to. And that can take some effort; when thereâ€™s something you need to redo, status quo bias(ç°çŠ¶åè§,å€¾å‘äºä¿æŒç°çŠ¶) and laziness will combine to keep you in denial about it. To beat this ask: If I'd already made the change, would I want to revert to what I have now?(æƒ³è±¡ä¸€ä¸‹æ”¹å˜åçš„æ ·å­,çœ‹çœ‹å“ªä¸ªæ›´å¥½.)

Have the confidence to cut. Donâ€™t keep something that doesnâ€™t fit just because you're proud of it(ä½ çš„"proud"ä¸å€¼ä¸€æ), or because it cost you a lot of effort(ä½ çš„"effort"ä¸å€¼ä¸€æ).

Indeed, in some kinds of work itâ€™s good to strip whatever youâ€™re doing to its essence. The result will be more concentrated; youâ€™ll understand it better; and you wonâ€™t be able to lie to yourself about whether thereâ€™s anything real there.

Mathematical elegance may sound like a mere metaphor, drawn from the arts. Thatâ€™s what I thought when I first heard the term â€œelegantâ€ applied to a proof. But now I suspect itâ€™s conceptually prior â€” that the main ingredient in artistic elegance is mathematical elegance. At any rate itâ€™s a useful standard well beyond math.

Elegance can be a long-term bet, though. Laborious solutions will often have more prestige in the short term. They cost a lot of effort and theyâ€™re hard to understand, both of which impress people, at least temporarily.

Whereas some of the very best work will seem like it took comparatively little effort, because it was in a sense already there. It didnâ€™t have to be built, just seen. It's a very good sign when it's hard to say whether you're creating something or discovering it.

When youâ€™re doing work that could be seen as either creation or discovery, err on the side of discovery. Try thinking of yourself as a mere conduit through which the ideas take their natural shape.

Great work will often be tool-like in the sense of being something others build on. So itâ€™s a good sign if youâ€™re creating ideas that others could use, or exposing questions that others could answer. The best ideas have implications in many different areas.

If you express your ideas in the most general form, theyâ€™ll be truer than you intended.

True by itself is not enough, of course. Great ideas have to be true and new. And it takes a certain amount of ability to see new ideas even once youâ€™ve learned enough to get to one of the frontiers of knowledge.

In English we give this ability names like originality, creativity, and imagination. And it seems reasonable to give it a separate name, because it does seem to some extent a separate skill. Itâ€™s possible to have a great deal of ability in other respects â€” to have a great deal of whatâ€™s often called â€œtechnical abilityâ€ â€” and yet not have much of this.

Iâ€™ve never liked the term â€œcreative process.â€ It seems misleading. Originality isnâ€™t a process, but a habit of mind. Original thinkers throw off new ideas about whatever they focus on, like an angle grinder throwing off sparks. They canâ€™t help it.

If the thing theyâ€™re focused on is something they donâ€™t understand very well, these new ideas might not be good. One of the most original thinkers I know decided to focus on dating after he got divorced. He knew roughly as much about dating as the average 15-year-old, and the results were spectacularly colorful. But to see originality separated from expertise like that made its nature all the more clear.

I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s possible to cultivate originality, but there are definitely ways to make the most of however much you have. For example, youâ€™re much more likely to have original ideas when youâ€™re working on something. Original ideas donâ€™t come from trying to have original ideas. They come from trying to build or understand something slightly too difficult.(é€‚å½“éš¾åº¦) [15]

Talking or writing about the things youâ€™re interested in is a good way to generate new ideas. When you try to put ideas into words, a missing idea creates a sort of vacuum that draws it out of you. Indeed, thereâ€™s a kind of thinking that can only be done by writing.

Changing your context can help. If you visit a new place, youâ€™ll often find you have new ideas there. The journey itself often dislodges them. But you may not have to go far to get this benefit. Sometimes itâ€™s enoughjust to go for a walk.[16]

It also helps to travel in topic space. Youâ€™ll have more new ideas if you explore lots of different topics, partly because it gives the angle grinder more surface area to work on, and partly because analogies are an especially fruitful source of new ideas.

Donâ€™t divide your attention evenly between many topics though, or youâ€™ll spread yourself too thin. You want to distribute it according to something more like a power law. [17] Be professionally curious about a few topics and idly(æ— ç›®çš„åœ°) curious about many more.

Curiosity and originality are closely related. Curiosity feeds originality by giving it new things to work on. But the relationship is closer than that. Curiosity is itself a kind of originality; it's roughly to questions what originality is to answers. And since questions at their best are a big component of answers, curiosity at its best is a creative force.

è¿™æ„å‘³ç€å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå’ŒåŸåˆ›æ€§æœ‰ç´§å¯†çš„è”ç³»ã€‚å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒé©±ä½¿äººä»¬å»æ¢ç´¢ã€å­¦ä¹ å’Œå°è¯•æ–°çš„äº‹ç‰©ï¼Œè€Œè¿™ç§æ¢ç´¢è¿‡ç¨‹å¾€å¾€ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿæ–°é¢–å’Œç‹¬ç‰¹çš„æ€è€ƒæˆ–åˆ›æ„ã€‚

â€œCuriosity feeds originality by giving it new things to work on.â€

å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒé¼“åŠ±æˆ‘ä»¬æ·±å…¥æ¢ç´¢æœªçŸ¥é¢†åŸŸï¼Œä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬çš„åŸåˆ›æ€§æä¾›äº†æ–°çš„ç´ æå’Œçµæ„Ÿã€‚ç®€å•æ¥è¯´ï¼Œå¥½å¥‡å¿ƒä¸ºåŸåˆ›æ€§â€œä¾›ç»™â€æ–°çš„ç´ ææˆ–ä¸»é¢˜ã€‚

â€œCuriosity is itself a kind of originality; itâ€™s roughly to questions what originality is to answers.â€

è¿™å¥è¯è¡¨è¾¾çš„æ˜¯å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒæœ¬èº«ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸€ç§åŸåˆ›æ€§çš„è¡¨ç°ã€‚å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒä¼šäº§ç”Ÿé—®é¢˜ï¼Œè€ŒåŸåˆ›æ€§åˆ™ä¸ºè¿™äº›é—®é¢˜æä¾›ç­”æ¡ˆã€‚æ¯”å–»åœ°è¯´ï¼Œå¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå¯¹äºæå‡ºé—®é¢˜å°±åƒåŸåˆ›æ€§å¯¹äºæä¾›ç­”æ¡ˆä¸€æ ·é‡è¦ã€‚

â€œAnd since questions at their best are a big component of answers, curiosity at its best is a creative force.â€

è¿™å¥è¯è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å¼ºè°ƒäº†é—®é¢˜çš„é‡è¦æ€§ã€‚å¥½çš„é—®é¢˜æœ¬èº«æ˜¯ç­”æ¡ˆçš„ä¸€ä¸ªé‡è¦ç»„æˆéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬æŒ‡å¼•å’Œé©±åŠ¨äº†æˆ‘ä»¬çš„æ€è€ƒå’Œæ¢ç´¢ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œå½“å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå¤„äºå…¶æœ€ä½³çŠ¶æ€æ—¶ï¼Œå®ƒå°±æˆä¸ºäº†ä¸€ä¸ªå¼ºå¤§çš„åˆ›é€ æ€§åŠ¨åŠ›ã€‚

å³:ç”±å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå‡ºå‘å¾—åˆ°çš„ç­”æ¡ˆå¾€å¾€ä¼šå…·æœ‰åŸåˆ›æ–°.

Part 4è‡ªä¿¡åœ°è£å‰ªï¼šä¸è¦å› ä¸ºå¯¹æŸç‰©è‡ªè±ªæˆ–ä¸ºå…¶ä»˜å‡ºäº†å·¨å¤§çš„åŠªåŠ›å°±ç•™ä¸‹å®ƒï¼Œå³ä½¿å®ƒä¸åˆé€‚ã€‚

è¿½æ±‚æœ¬è´¨ï¼šå°†å·¥ä½œç®€åŒ–è‡³å…¶æ ¸å¿ƒï¼Œç»“æœä¼šæ›´åŠ çº¯ç²¹ï¼Œæ›´å®¹æ˜“ç†è§£ã€‚
æ•°å­¦ä¸è‰ºæœ¯çš„ä¼˜é›…ï¼šè‰ºæœ¯ä¸­çš„ä¼˜é›…ä¸æ•°å­¦ä¸­çš„ä¼˜é›…ç´§å¯†ç›¸è¿ï¼Œä¼˜é›…å¾€å¾€è¶…å‡ºäº†æ•°å­¦çš„èŒƒå›´ã€‚

ä¼˜é›…ä¸åŠªåŠ›ï¼šè™½ç„¶ç¹ççš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆå¯èƒ½çŸ­æœŸå†…æ›´å—è®¤å¯ï¼Œä½†çœŸæ­£ä¼˜é›…çš„å·¥ä½œå¯èƒ½çœ‹èµ·æ¥ä¸éœ€è¦é‚£ä¹ˆå¤šåŠªåŠ›ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒå·²ç»å­˜åœ¨ã€‚

åˆ›é€ ä¸å‘ç°ï¼šå½“ä½ æ— æ³•ç¡®å®šä½ æ˜¯åœ¨åˆ›é€ è¿˜æ˜¯å‘ç°æ—¶ï¼Œæ›´å¤šåœ°è€ƒè™‘è‡ªå·±æ˜¯å‘ç°çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚

å·¥å…·çš„åŠ›é‡ï¼šåˆ›å»ºå¼ºå¤§çš„å·¥å…·æ—¶ï¼Œåº”å°½é‡æ¶ˆé™¤é™åˆ¶ï¼Œä½¿å…¶åœ¨æœªé¢„è§çš„æ–¹å¼ä¸Šå‘æŒ¥ä½œç”¨ã€‚

é‡è¦æ€§çš„åˆ›æ„ï¼šä¼Ÿå¤§çš„åˆ›æ„å¸¸å¸¸åƒå·¥å…·ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œå…¶ä»–äººå¯ä»¥åŸºäºæ­¤æ„å»ºã€‚

åŸåˆ›æ€§çš„æœ¬è´¨ï¼šåŸåˆ›æ€§ä¸ä»…ä»…æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹ï¼Œå®ƒæ˜¯ä¸€ç§æ€ç»´ä¹ æƒ¯ï¼Œä¸ä¾èµ–äºæŸä¸ªé¢†åŸŸçš„ä¸“ä¸šçŸ¥è¯†ã€‚

æé«˜åŸåˆ›æ€§ï¼šå·¥ä½œã€å†™ä½œã€äº¤æµã€æ”¹å˜ç¯å¢ƒã€æ¢ç´¢ä¸åŒçš„ä¸»é¢˜éƒ½å¯ä»¥æ¿€å‘åŸåˆ›æ€§ã€‚

å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒä¸åŸåˆ›æ€§ï¼šå¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå’ŒåŸåˆ›æ€§ç´§å¯†ç›¸è¿ï¼Œå¥½å¥‡å¿ƒæœ¬èº«å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ç§åˆ›æ–°ï¼›å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå¯¹é—®é¢˜çš„æ€åº¦ä¸åŸåˆ›æ€§å¯¹ç­”æ¡ˆçš„æ€åº¦ç›¸ä¼¼ã€‚

å°†ä»¥ä¸Šçš„ä¿¡æ¯æ€»ç»“æˆä¸€ä¸ªå‡ç»ƒçš„çŸ­è¯­, æˆ–è€…çŸ­å¥, ç»“å°¾é…ä¸Šä¸€ä¸ªemoji.ç»™æˆ‘å››ä¸ªç‰ˆæœ¬.

Having new ideas is a strange game, because it usually consists of seeing things that were right under your nose. Once youâ€™ve seen a new idea, it tends to seem obvious. Why did no one think of this before?

When an idea seems simultaneously novel and obvious, itâ€™s probably a good one.

Seeing something obvious sounds easy. And yet empirically having new ideas is hard. Whatâ€™s the source of this apparent contradiction? Itâ€™s that seeing the new idea usually requires you to change the way you look at the world. We see the world through models that both help and constrain us. When you fix a broken model, new ideas become obvious. But noticing and fixing a broken model is hard. Thatâ€™s how new ideas can be both obvious and yet hard to discover: theyâ€™re easy to see after you do something hard.

One way to discover broken models is to be stricter than other people. Broken models of the world leave a trail of clues where they bash against reality. Most people donâ€™t want to see these clues. It would be an understatement to say that theyâ€™re attached to their current model; itâ€™s what they think in; so theyâ€™ll tend to ignore the trail of clues left by its breakage, however conspicuous it may seem in retrospect.

To find new ideas you have to seize on signs of breakage instead of looking away. Thatâ€™s what Einstein did. He was able to see the wild implications of Maxwellâ€™s equations not so much because he was looking for new ideas as because he was stricter.

The other thing you need is a willingness to break rules. Paradoxical as it sounds, if you want to fix your model of the world, it helps to be the sort of person whoâ€™s comfortable breaking rules. From the point of view of the old model, which everyone including you initially shares, the new model usually breaks at least implicit rules.

Few understand the degree of rule-breaking required, because new ideas seem much more conservative once they succeed. They seem perfectly reasonable once youâ€™re using the new model of the world they brought with them. But they didnâ€™t at the time; it took the greater part of a century for the heliocentric model to be generally accepted, even among astronomers, because it felt so wrong.

Indeed, if you think about it, a good new idea has to seem bad to most people, or someone would have already explored it. So what youâ€™re looking for is ideas that seem crazy, but the right kind of crazy. How do you recognize these? You canâ€™t with certainty. Often ideas that seem bad are bad. But ideas that are the right kind of crazy tend to be exciting; theyâ€™re rich in implications; whereas ideas that are merely bad tend to be depressing.

There are two ways to be comfortable breaking rules: to enjoy breaking them, and to be indifferent to them. I call these two cases being aggressively and passively independent-minded.

The aggressively independent-minded are the naughty ones. Rules donâ€™t merely fail to stop them; breaking rules gives them additional energy. For this sort of person, delight at the sheer audacity of a project sometimes supplies enough activation energy to get it started.

The other way to break rules is not to care about them, or perhaps even to know they exist. This is why novices and outsiders often make new discoveries; their ignorance of a fieldâ€™s assumptions acts as a source of temporary passive independent-mindedness. Aspies also seem to have a kind of immunity to conventional beliefs. Several I know say that this helps them to have new ideas.

Strictness plus rule-breaking sounds like a strange combination. In popular culture theyâ€™re opposed. But popular culture has a broken model in this respect. It implicitly assumes that issues are trivial ones, and in trivial matters strictness and rule-breaking are opposed. But in questions that really matter, only rule-breakers can be truly strict.

entry.title: New research helps explain why Chinas low birth are stuck ç»æµå­¦äººç²¾è¯» Economist
entry.content:
æœ¬ç«™èƒŒæ™¯éŸ³ä¹å¯å·¦ä¸‹è§’æš‚åœ,ä¸‹æ–¹æ˜¯è¯¥ç¯‡æ–‡ç« çš„æœ—è¯»ç‰ˆéŸ³é¢‘,æœ‰éœ€æ±‚å¯ä»¥æ’­æ”¾(å¦‚æœä¸èƒ½æ˜¾ç¤º,å¯ä»¥ç‚¹å‡»é“¾æ¥:ç½‘æ˜“äº‘_Chinaâ€™s young want to work):

New research helps explain why Chinaâ€™s low birth rates are stuck

Spillover effects may be to blame

THE SCARS(ä¼¤ç–¤) left by Chinaâ€™s population-control policies are clear. Last year, its population started to fall for the first time since 1962; its working-age population has been declining for a decade. A shrinking workforce acts as a drag(æ‹–ç´¯äº†) on growth, and a swelling number of elderly puts pressure on the welfare system(ç¦åˆ©ä½“ç³»).

Family-planning(ç”Ÿè‚²æ”¿ç­–) regulations like the one-child policy are widely blamed for depressing birth rates. But a less explored idea is that falling birth rates can ripple through the population(åœ¨ç¾¤ä½“ä¸­äº§ç”Ÿè¿é”ååº”) causing the decline to be self- reinforcing(è¿™ä¸ªç°è±¡ä¼šå¯¹ç°è±¡æœ¬èº«äº§ç”Ÿæ­£åé¦ˆè€ŒåŠ å¼º/æ¶æ€§å¾ªç¯). There has been little hard evidence to back this up, but a new paper about changes in China 50 years ago appears to offer some proof. Pauline Rossi of Ecole Polytechnique in Paris and Yun Xiao of the University of Gothenburg show(å‘è¡¨æ–‡ç« ç§°) in the Journal of the European Economic Association that birth-control policies have â€œspillover effectsâ€, meaning that if some couples reduce their number of children, it may lead others to follow suit(æ•ˆä»¿).

follow suit å­¦æ ·

When one company introduces a new product others often follow suit.

Professors Rossi and Xiao examine fertility data for women born between 1926 and 1945. This cohort was of reproductive age(å¤„äºç”Ÿè‚²å¹´é¾„) when the â€œlater, longer and fewerâ€ (LLF) campaign of the 1970s, the first of Chinaâ€™s family-planning policies, began. It encouraged couples to marry later, wait longer between children and have fewer of them. Much of Chinaâ€™s fertility decline happened during this period. In 1969, the total fertility rate (the average number of children a woman is expected to have over her lifetime at current birth rates) was 6.2, according to the World Bank; a decade later, when the one-child policy was introduced, it had already fallen to 2.7.

Crucially(é‡è¦çš„æ˜¯), the LLF campaign targeted only the main ethnic group, the Han. That allowed the authors to study how ethnic-minority groups, who were exempt from(è±å…) it, responded. After controlling for other factors, they found that the policy did not affect minorities who lived apart from the Han. For those who lived among the Han, however, it led to a decline in fertilityâ€” what the authors suggest is evidence of spillovers(æº¢å‡ºæ•ˆåº”). The greater the share of Han in the prefecture(å¿,å±…ä½åŒº), the stronger the effect.

Spillover effects may work in two ways. First, couples who have fewer children have more resources to invest per child. Other couples may feel compelled(æœ‰å¿…è¦/è¢«è¿«) to emulate(æ•ˆä»¿) them if they want to compete, especially in areas such as education. A second way is through social conformity(ä»ä¼—). As some couples have fewer children, this may influence others to limit the number of children they have, too. The authors found that minorities culturally closer to the Han were affected more by the LLF.

China is not the only place affected by spillovers. They have been found in South Korea, too, another country with a low fertility rate and punitively expensive education. Many children there attend private tuition classes, known as hagwon, late into the evening. Seongeun Kim of Sejong University and others found that when wealthy families spent less on private classes, it led lower-income families to do the same. Spillovers may happen where people have strong economic or social incentives to keep up with others.

spillover

â€œSpilloversâ€ åœ¨è¿™é‡Œæ„å‘³ç€æŸç§è¡Œä¸ºæˆ–å†³ç­–çš„å½±å“ä»ä¸€ä¸ªç¾¤ä½“â€œæº¢å‡ºâ€åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªç¾¤ä½“ã€‚åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­ï¼Œå¯Œè£•å®¶åº­çš„æ¶ˆè´¹å†³ç­–äº§ç”Ÿäº†ä¸€ä¸ªâ€œæº¢å‡ºâ€æ•ˆåº”ï¼Œå½±å“äº†ä½æ”¶å…¥å®¶åº­ã€‚åŸå› å¯èƒ½æ˜¯äººä»¬æœ‰å¾ˆå¼ºçš„ç»æµæˆ–ç¤¾ä¼šåŠ¨æœºå»è·Ÿä¸Šå…¶ä»–äººã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå¦‚æœä¸€ä¸ªç¤¾åŒºä¸­çš„å¤šæ•°å®¶åº­éƒ½åœæ­¢å‘é€ä»–ä»¬çš„å­©å­å»å‚åŠ æ˜‚è´µçš„ç§äººè¯¾ç¨‹ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå…¶ä»–å®¶åº­å¯èƒ½ä¹Ÿä¼šè§‰å¾—ä¸åº”è¯¥æ˜¯å”¯ä¸€ç»§ç»­æ”¯ä»˜è¿™ç§è´¹ç”¨çš„å®¶åº­ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™å¯èƒ½åœ¨ç¤¾äº¤æˆ–æ–‡åŒ–ä¸Šè¢«è§†ä¸ºâ€œä¸ä¼—ä¸åŒâ€æˆ–â€œæµªè´¹â€ã€‚

äººç¾¤çš„ä»ä¼—å¿ƒç†æ˜¯å› ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆ?ä½ è§‰å¾—è¿™ç§ä»ä¼—å¿ƒç†æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆåº•å±‚çš„é€»è¾‘?

äººç¾¤çš„ä»ä¼—å¿ƒç†æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¤æ‚çš„ç°è±¡ï¼Œå…¶èƒŒåæœ‰å¤šç§å¿ƒç†ã€ç”Ÿç‰©å­¦å’Œç¤¾ä¼šå­¦åŸå› ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯ä¸€äº›å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´ä»ä¼—å¿ƒç†çš„åŸå› åŠå…¶åº•å±‚é€»è¾‘ï¼š

ç”Ÿç‰©å­¦åŸå› ï¼šä»è¿›åŒ–çš„è§’åº¦çœ‹ï¼Œæˆä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªç¤¾ç¾¤çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å¯ä»¥æé«˜ç”Ÿå­˜å’Œç¹æ®–çš„æœºä¼šã€‚å¤ä»£çš„äººç±»ä¾èµ–å›¢ä½“æ¥å…±åŒç‹©çŒã€æœé›†é£Ÿç‰©å’Œé˜²å¾¡å¤–æ¥å¨èƒã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œé€‚åº”å¹¶èå…¥å¤§å¤šæ•°äººçš„è¡Œä¸ºå’Œä¿¡ä»°å¯èƒ½æ˜¯ä¸€ç§ç”Ÿå­˜ç­–ç•¥ã€‚

å¯¹è®¤åŒçš„éœ€æ±‚ï¼šäººç±»æœ‰ä¸€ç§å¤©ç”Ÿçš„éœ€è¦ï¼Œé‚£å°±æ˜¯è¢«ç¤¾åŒºæˆ–å›¢ä½“æ¥å—å’Œè®¤åŒã€‚ä»ä¼—å¯ä»¥ä½¿äººæ„Ÿåˆ°æ›´åŠ å®‰å…¨ï¼Œå‡å°‘è¢«æ’æ–¥æˆ–å­¤ç«‹çš„é£é™©ã€‚

ä¿¡æ¯ä¸ç¡®å®šæ€§ï¼šå½“ä¸ªä½“ä¸ç¡®å®šè‡ªå·±çš„å†³ç­–æˆ–çœ‹æ³•æ—¶ï¼Œä»–ä»¬å¯èƒ½ä¼šä¾èµ–å…¶ä»–äººçš„æ„è§å’Œè¡Œä¸ºã€‚è¿™è¢«è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯ä¸€ç§â€œç¤¾ä¼šè¯æ˜â€ï¼Œå³å¦‚æœå¤šæ•°äººéƒ½è¿™ä¹ˆåšæˆ–è¿™ä¹ˆè®¤ä¸ºï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå®ƒå¯èƒ½æ˜¯æ­£ç¡®çš„ã€‚

å‡å°‘å¿ƒç†ä¸é€‚ï¼šä¸å¤§å¤šæ•°äººæŒæœ‰ç›¸åçš„è§‚ç‚¹æˆ–è¡Œä¸ºå¯èƒ½ä¼šå¸¦æ¥å¿ƒç†ä¸é€‚æˆ–ç´§å¼ ã€‚ä»ä¼—å¯ä»¥é¿å…è¿™ç§ä¸é€‚ï¼Œä½¿äººæ„Ÿåˆ°æ›´åŠ èˆ’é€‚å’Œè‡ªåœ¨ã€‚

ç¤¾ä¼šå‹åŠ›ï¼šåœ¨è®¸å¤šæ–‡åŒ–å’Œç¤¾ä¼šä¸­ï¼Œä¸ä»ä¼—å¯èƒ½ä¼šå¸¦æ¥ç›´æ¥çš„åæœï¼Œå¦‚è¢«å˜²ç¬‘ã€è¢«æ’æ–¥æˆ–å…¶ä»–å½¢å¼çš„æƒ©ç½šã€‚

ä»ä¼—å¿ƒç†çš„åº•å±‚é€»è¾‘ä¸»è¦å›´ç»•äººçš„ç¤¾ä¼šç”Ÿç‰©å­¦éœ€è¦ï¼Œä»¥åŠåœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªç¾¤ä½“ä¸­å¯»æ±‚å®‰å…¨ã€æ¥å—å’Œè®¤åŒçš„éœ€æ±‚ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œè¿™ç§å¿ƒç†ä¹Ÿæœ‰å…¶ç¼ºç‚¹ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´å›¢ä½“æ€ç»´æˆ–é˜»ç¢åˆ›æ–°ã€‚å°½ç®¡å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œåœ¨è®¸å¤šæƒ…å¢ƒä¸­ï¼Œä»ä¼—å¿ƒç†æ˜¯æœ‰ç›Šçš„ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å¸®åŠ©ç»´æŒç¤¾ä¼šç¨³å®šå’Œå’Œè°ã€‚

For China, the implications are grim(å½±å“æ˜¯ä¸¥å³»çš„). The government has belatedly tried to prod couples into(é¼“åŠ±) having more children, with little success. Even though the one-child policy ended in 2016 and China switched to a three-child policy in 2021, birth rates have not rebounded. The fertility rate fell to 1.2 in 2021, a record low. The high cost of having children means couples want fewer of them. Low birth rates are in turn reinforced by spillovers, leading more couples to follow suit. Without `external impetus(åŠ¨åŠ›)`, China cannot escape this trap.

What can be done? Theoretically, if spillovers work in reverse, getting one segment of the population to have more children could have an impact. To this end(ä¸ºæ­¤), Chinaâ€™s leaders have tried to crack down on private tutoring(æ‰“å‡»ç§äººè¾…å¯¼) in order to slow the education arms race. They could also incentivise(æ¿€åŠ±) couples through payments(å¥–åŠ±) or benefits for extra kids. But experience suggests that such policies yield meagre results(æ”¶æ•ˆç”šå¾®). China is finding that it was much easier to use force to restrict the number of births than it is to increase it. â– 

Subscribers can sign up to Drum Tower, our new weekly newsletter, to understand what the world makes of Chinaâ€”and what China makes of the world.

entry.title: China's young want to work ç»æµå­¦äººç²¾è¯» Economist
entry.content:
æœ¬ç«™èƒŒæ™¯éŸ³ä¹å¯å·¦ä¸‹è§’æš‚åœ,ä¸‹æ–¹æ˜¯è¯¥ç¯‡æ–‡ç« çš„æœ—è¯»ç‰ˆéŸ³é¢‘,æœ‰éœ€æ±‚å¯ä»¥æ’­æ”¾(å¦‚æœä¸èƒ½æ˜¾ç¤º,å¯ä»¥ç‚¹å‡»é“¾æ¥:ç½‘æ˜“äº‘_Chinaâ€™s young want to work):

The job search goes on
Chinaâ€™s young want to work.
For the government Youth unemployment is now shockingly high

CHINA IS A land of remarkable statistics. But an official figure published on May 16th still managed to stand out. The unemployment rate among Chinaâ€™s urban youth, aged between 16 and 24, exceeded one in five in April.

The figure boggles the mind(è®©äººéš¾ä»¥ç½®ä¿¡) for a variety of reasons. China is running short of young people. It is trying, without much success, to raise the birth rate. Its economic future hangs on(å–å†³äº) increased education, which could improve the quality of its workers even as their quantity declines. China is also famous for mobilising resources, including manpower. Yet it is wasting large numbers of the best-educated cohort(äººæ‰) it has ever produced.

hang onä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯å–å†³äº?

â€œHang onâ€æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªéå¸¸å¤šåŠŸèƒ½çš„çŸ­è¯­ï¼Œæ ¹æ®ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡å®ƒå¯ä»¥æœ‰å¤šç§æ„æ€ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼š
ç­‰ä¸€ä¸‹: â€œHang on a minute!â€
ä¾èµ–ï¼š â€œOur decision hangs on the results of the survey.â€
åšæŒï¼š â€œJust hang on, help is on the way.â€
è¯æ±‡çš„å«ä¹‰ç»å¸¸æ˜¯åŸºäºå…¶å†å²å’Œæ–‡åŒ–çš„èƒŒæ™¯æ¼”å˜çš„ã€‚â€Hangâ€åŸæ„æ˜¯â€æ‚¬æŒ‚â€ï¼Œè€Œâ€onâ€å¯ä»¥è¡¨ç¤ºæ–¹å‘æˆ–ä¾é™„ã€‚ä»å­—é¢æ„æ€ä¸Šæ¥çœ‹ï¼Œâ€œæ‚¬æŒ‚åœ¨â€¦ä¸Šâ€å¯èƒ½æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯ç‰©ä½“æˆ–äº‹æƒ…çš„å­˜ç»­ã€æŒç»­æˆ–ä¾èµ–äºå¦ä¸€ç‰©ä½“æˆ–æƒ…å†µã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªç”»åƒæŒ‚åœ¨å¢™ä¸Šï¼Œå®ƒçš„ä½ç½®ä¾èµ–äºå¢™ã€‚è¿™æ ·çš„ç›´è§‚å«ä¹‰å¯èƒ½ä½¿â€hang onâ€é€æ¸ä¸â€ä¾èµ–â€æˆ–â€å–å†³äºâ€çš„æ„æ€è”ç³»åœ¨ä¸€èµ·ã€‚

Youth unemployment is puzzling, as well as surprising. It has increased even as Chinaâ€™s economy has reopened after the sudden end of its zero-covid regime in December. It has jumped up(å¤§å¹…ä¸Šå‡) while the overall unemployment rate has edged(å°å¹…ä¸‹é™) downwards (from 6.1% in April 2022 to 5.2% a year later). And it is likely to rise further in the next few months. This year, a record 11.6m students will graduate from university, an increase of almost 40% since 2019. They include Wang Lili, who will leave one of Chinaâ€™s top-100 universities this year with a degree in management. â€œThe market is terrible,â€ she laments. â€œMany graduates are very anxious.â€

æè¿°æ•°æ®å˜åŒ–



Spiral: å¯ä»¥è¡¨ç¤ºè¿…é€Ÿä¸Šå‡orä¸‹é™

The number of unemployed youth (about 6.3m in the first three months of this year) is small relative to Chinaâ€™s 486m-strong(é€¾) urban workforce. But they attract most of the attention, points out(æŒ‡å‡º) Xiangrong Yu of Citigroup, a bank, and his colleagues. The anxiety and disappointment felt by college studentsâ€”and spread through social mediaâ€”could â€œaffect the confidence of the entire societyâ€, write Zhuo Xian and his co-authors at the Development Research Centre (DRC), a government think-tank(æ™ºåº“).

Although the problem has outlasted(still exists even after) the pandemic, it is partly caused by it. When covid struck, many Chinese chose to extend their studies. In 2020, for example, the Ministry of Education told universities to increase the number of Masterâ€™s students by over 20%. That has created a bulge of(æ¿€å¢) newly minted(æ–°å‡ºç°çš„/åˆšåˆšäº§ç”Ÿçš„) graduates entering the labour force in subsequent years.

Chinaâ€™s reopening may have tempted many of those who had dropped out of the job market to re-engage before firms were ready to hire them. The bottleneck has been aggravated(åŠ å‰§) by mismatches in timing, skills and aspirations. Some graduates delayed their job hunt last year to prepare for entrance exams for higher degrees or the civil service. But employers last year wanted to fill their ranks(å¡«è¡¥å‘˜å·¥é˜Ÿä¼) early because of fears of a winter covid wave. So later job-seekers missed the best recruitment months and many are now competing for the same jobs as students leaving university in 2023.
(å› æ­¤ï¼Œåæ¥çš„(è€Œä¸æ˜¯åæ¥)æ±‚èŒè€…é”™è¿‡äº†æœ€å¥½çš„æ‹›è˜æœˆä»½ï¼Œè®¸å¤šäººç°åœ¨éƒ½åœ¨ç«äº‰ä¸2023å¹´å¤§å­¦æ¯•ä¸šç”Ÿç›¸åŒçš„å·¥ä½œã€‚)

è¿™ä¸€æ®µç¬¬ä¸€å¥å¦‚ä½•ç†è§£?

è¿™å¥è¯æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œå½“ä¸­å›½é‡æ–°å¼€æ”¾æ—¶ï¼Œè®¸å¤šä¹‹å‰é€€å‡ºå·¥ä½œå¸‚åœºçš„äººå¯èƒ½è¢«å¸å¼•å›æ¥å¹¶é‡æ–°å‚ä¸åˆ°æ±‚èŒä¸­ï¼Œå³ä½¿å…¬å¸è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰å‡†å¤‡å¥½é›‡ä½£ä»–ä»¬ã€‚è®©æˆ‘ä»¬é€æ­¥è§£æè¿™å¥è¯ä»¥å¸®åŠ©ä½ ç†è§£ï¼š

  • 2:tempted many of those who had dropped out of the job marketï¼šè¿™é‡Œçš„â€œtemptedâ€æ„ä¸ºâ€œå¸å¼•â€ã€‚è€Œâ€œthose who had dropped out of the job marketâ€æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯é‚£äº›ä¹‹å‰å› å„ç§åŸå› ï¼ˆå¯èƒ½æ˜¯ç»æµã€å¥åº·æˆ–å…¶ä»–å› ç´ ï¼‰è€Œé€€å‡ºå·¥ä½œå¸‚åœºçš„äººã€‚

  • 3:to re-engage before firms were ready to hire themï¼šè¿™æ„å‘³ç€è¿™äº›äººè¢«å¸å¼•å›æ¥å¹¶æƒ³å†æ¬¡æ‰¾å·¥ä½œï¼Œä½†é—®é¢˜æ˜¯ï¼Œå°½ç®¡ä»–ä»¬æƒ³è¦å·¥ä½œï¼Œå…¬å¸å´è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰å‡†å¤‡å¥½é›‡ä½£ä»–ä»¬ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œç®€è€Œè¨€ä¹‹ï¼Œè¿™å¥è¯çš„æ„æ€æ˜¯ï¼šéšç€ä¸­å›½çš„é‡æ–°å¼€æ”¾ï¼Œè®¸å¤šä¹‹å‰ç¦»å¼€å·¥ä½œå¸‚åœºçš„äººæƒ³è¦å›æ¥æ‰¾å·¥ä½œï¼Œä½†å…¬å¸å¯èƒ½è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰å‡†å¤‡å¥½æˆ–æ²¡æœ‰è¶³å¤Ÿçš„èŒä½ä¾›ä»–ä»¬é€‰æ‹©ã€‚è¿™å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´æ±‚èŒè€…ä¸é›‡ä¸»ä¹‹é—´çš„é”™é…ï¼Œå› ä¸ºé›‡ä¸»å¯èƒ½è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰åšå¥½é›‡ä½£å¤§é‡æ–°å‘˜å·¥çš„å‡†å¤‡ã€‚
å…¶å®,è¿™é‡Œå¯ä»¥å’Œæœ¬æ®µç¬¬äºŒå¥ä¸€èµ·ç»“åˆç†è§£.


Some of them boast(æ‹¥æœ‰/å…·å¤‡) qualifications that are out of sync with the new demands of the economy. Platforms like Alibaba, property firms(æˆ¿åœ°äº§å…¬å¸) like Evergrande(grandeur å£®ä¸½,é›„ä¼Ÿ), and online tutors(åœ¨çº¿æ•™è‚²) like New Oriental were once dream employers for graduates. But in the time it takes to earn a bachelorâ€™s degree, they have lost favour with the government.

boast: æ‹¥æœ‰/å¤¸è€€

Chinaâ€™s leaders now fear what they call the â€œdisorderly expansion of capitalâ€(èµ„æœ¬æ— åºæ‰©å¼ ) in sectors(é¢†åŸŸ) like property and education, as well as the market power and cultural reach(æ–‡åŒ–å½±å“åŠ›) of tech firms. Recruitment has therefore slowed. Only 5.5% of students graduating this year expect to go into the education and training industries, according to a survey by Zhaopin, a recruitment portal.

Some graduates now adopt a â€œspray and prayâ€(ç›²æŠ•) approach, as Ms Wang (not her real name) puts it, submitting applications willy-nilly. The government is keen to steer talent into â€œhard techâ€ industries, such as aerospace, biotechnology and electric vehicles. They are promoted in the latest five-year plan and have grown faster than industry as a whole, says Louise Loo of Oxford Economics, a consultancy. Employment may follow. According to the recent Zhaopin survey, 57% of engineers graduating this year had already received a job offer, compared with only 41% of their counterparts(ç›¸å¯¹åº”çš„/ç›¸ä¼¼çš„,æ­¤å¤„æŒ‡æ¯•ä¸šç”Ÿ) in the humanities(äººæ–‡å­¦ç§‘).

willy-nilly

â€œWilly-nillyâ€ åŸæœ¬æ˜¯â€œwill he, nill heâ€çš„ç¼©å†™ï¼Œç›´è¯‘ä¸ºâ€œä»–æ„¿æ„ï¼Œä»–ä¸æ„¿æ„â€ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºä¸ç®¡æŸäººæ˜¯å¦æ„¿æ„ï¼ŒæŸäº‹éƒ½ä¼šå‘ç”Ÿã€‚è¿™ä¸ªçŸ­è¯­çš„ä½¿ç”¨å¯ä»¥è¿½æº¯åˆ°14ä¸–çºªã€‚ç°åœ¨ï¼Œâ€œwilly-nillyâ€é€šå¸¸ç”¨æ¥æè¿°æŸäº‹æ˜¯éšæœºã€æ²¡æœ‰è®¡åˆ’æˆ–æ˜¯å¿…ç„¶çš„ã€‚

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œåœ¨æ‚¨æä¾›çš„å¥å­ä¸­ï¼Œâ€œwilly-nillyâ€ è¡¨ç¤ºåº”å±Šæ¯•ä¸šç”Ÿéšæ„ã€æ— è®¡åˆ’åœ°æäº¤å·¥ä½œç”³è¯·ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯æ ¹æ®ç‰¹å®šçš„å·¥ä½œæˆ–å…´è¶£è¿›è¡Œé€‰æ‹©ã€‚

ä»è¯æºå’Œå†å²èƒŒæ™¯æ¥çœ‹ï¼Œâ€willy-nillyâ€ çš„èµ·æºå¹¶ä¸æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†æè¿°éšæœºæˆ–æ— è®¡åˆ’çš„è¡ŒåŠ¨ï¼Œä½†éšç€æ—¶é—´çš„æ¨ç§»ï¼Œå®ƒçš„ç”¨æ³•å·²ç»æ¼”å˜ï¼Œç°åœ¨æ›´å¸¸ç”¨æ¥æè¿°è¿™ç§è¡Œä¸ºã€‚

One of the oddities(å¥‡æ€ªç°è±¡) of Chinaâ€™s labour market is that less-educated youth are less likely to be unemployed. Youngsters with vocational qualifications(èŒä¸šèµ„æ ¼è¯ä¹¦) or just a high-school education may have more practical skills and a more burning need(è¿«åˆ‡çš„éœ€æ±‚) for a job. â€œEveryone says a degree is a stepping stone,â€(open sesame æ•²é—¨ç –) said one hapless(å€’éœ‰çš„) graduate in an online comment translated by China Digital Times, a media-monitoring website, â€œbut Iâ€™m slowly coming to realise itâ€™s more like a pedestal I canâ€™t get down from.â€

æœ€åä¸€å¥?

è¿™éƒ¨åˆ†æ­ç¤ºäº†è¯¥æ¯•ä¸šç”Ÿçš„æ„Ÿå—ã€‚è¿™é‡Œçš„â€œpedestalâ€å¯ä»¥ç†è§£ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªé«˜é«˜çš„åŸºåº§æˆ–è€…æŸ±å­ã€‚ä¸€æ—¦ç«™ä¸Šå»ï¼Œå¾ˆéš¾å†ä¸‹æ¥ã€‚è¿™æ„å‘³ç€ï¼Œå°½ç®¡ä»–æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå­¦ä½ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªå­¦ä½åè€Œæˆä¸ºäº†é™åˆ¶ä»–çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå› ç´ ã€‚ä»–å¯èƒ½å‘ç°è‡ªå·±å› ä¸ºå­¦ä½è€Œè¢«é™åˆ¶åœ¨æŸç§ç‰¹å®šçš„è§’è‰²æˆ–æœŸæœ›ä¸­ï¼Œè€Œæ— æ³•è·å¾—é‚£äº›éœ€è¦å®é™…æŠ€èƒ½æˆ–ä¸åŒæŠ€èƒ½çš„å·¥ä½œæœºä¼šã€‚

Studentsâ€™ aspirations may be changing. The proportion choosing to continue their studies (at home or abroad) fell by almost half in this yearâ€™s Zhaopin survey. Students are also keen on stability and security. The share who rank(~ as first choice:å°†..ä½œä¸ºé¦–é€‰) state-owned enterprises(å›½æœ‰ä¼ä¸š) (SOEs) as their first choice has increased for three years in a row(è¿ç»­) to 47%, compared with 27% who favour a foreign-financed or domestic private firm(å›½å†…æ°‘è¥ä¼ä¸š). The remaining quarter wish to work for the government or public institutions.

The governmentâ€™s response to record youth unemployment may reinforce(åŠ å¼º) these trends. The State Council(å›½åŠ¡é™¢), Chinaâ€™s cabinet(å†…é˜), has urged local governments to recruit as many graduates as their budgets allow. It has also called on enterprises to create at least 1m internships for unemployed youth, in return for(ä»¥æ¢å–) subsidies(è¡¥è´´) and tax breaks(ç¨æ”¶å‡å…). The offer is open to all firms, but SOEs are most likely to heed the call(å¬æŒ‡ä»¤,heed the call of duty). These initiatives(ä¸¾æª) risk drawing some of Chinaâ€™s better-educated minds into some of the least efficient parts of its economy.

But for young folk, stop-gap(æƒå®œä¹‹è®¡,ä¸´æ—¶è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆ) measures do at least alleviate(å‡è½») some of the worry and confusion. Ms Wang, for example, has combined her studies over the past two years with an internship at a foreign firm. That gave her â€œsomething to do every dayâ€, she says, and also led to a satisfying job
offerâ€”in human resources. With luck, she will enjoy a long career helping China use those resources better. â– 

stop-gap

è¿™ä¸ªè¯æ±‡æœ€æ—©çš„ä½¿ç”¨å¯ä»¥è¿½æº¯åˆ°16ä¸–çºªçš„è‹±æ ¼å…°ï¼Œé‚£æ—¶å®ƒä¸»è¦è¢«ç”¨ä½œåè¯ã€‚åœ¨é‚£ä¸ªæ—¶æœŸï¼Œäººä»¬å¯èƒ½ä¼šç”¨ç‰©ç†çš„â€œstop-gapâ€æ¥é˜»æ­¢æ¶²ä½“æ³„æ¼æˆ–ä¿æŒé£ä¸è¿›å…¥æŸå¤„ã€‚

entry.title: Ai is setting off a great scramble for data ç»æµå­¦äººç²¾è¯»Economist
entry.content:
AI is setting off a great scramble for data

Feeding ever-larger models is requiring makers to get creative

Not so long ago analysts were openly wondering whether artificial intelligence (ai) would be the death of(æœ«æ—¥) Adobe, a maker of software for creative types. New tools like dall-e 2 and Midjourney, which conjure up(å¦‚é­”æ³•èˆ¬å˜å‡º) pictures from text, seemed set to render(ä½¿çœ‹èµ·æ¥) Adobeâ€™s image-editing offerings redundant(å†—ä½™). As recently as April, Seeking Alpha, a financial news site, published an article headlined â€œIs ai the Adobe killer?â€

Far from it.(åœ°é“è¡¨è¾¾) Adobe has used its database of hundreds of millions of stock photos to build its own suite(å¥—) of ai tools, dubbed(ç§°ä¸º) Firefly. Since its release in March the software has been used to create over 1bn(10^9,åäº¿) images, says Dana Rao, an executive at the company. By avoiding mining the internet for images, as rivals did, Adobe has skirted(å›é¿) the deepening dispute over copyright that now dogs(å›°æ‰°) the industry. The firmâ€™s share price has risen by 36% since Firefly was launched.

Adobeâ€™s triumph over the doomsters(æœ«æ—¥è®ºè€…) illustrates a wider point about the contest for dominance in the fast-developing market for ai tools. The supersized(è¶…å¤§çš„) models powering the latest wave of so-called â€œgenerativeâ€ ai rely on gargantuan(æµ·é‡çš„) amounts of data. Having already helped themselves to(treat oneself to x å¸®åŠ©è‡ªå·±è·å– âˆš æœªç»è®¸å¯åœ°å ç”¨ âˆš ) much of the internetâ€”often without permissionâ€”model builders are now seeking out new data sources to sustain the feeding frenzy(ç‹‚çƒ­). Meanwhile, companies with vast troves(è´®è—) of the stuff are weighing up(æƒè¡¡) how best to profit from it. A data land grab is under way.

The two essential ingredients for an ai model are datasets, on which the system is trained, and processing power, through which the model detects relationships within and among those datasets. Those two ingredients are, to an extent, substitutes(è¿™é‡ŒæŒ‡ç›¸äº’æ›¿ä»£): a model can be improved either by ingesting more data or adding more processing power. The latter, however, is becoming difficult amid(æ­£å¤„å½“ä¸‹) a shortage in specialist ai chips, leading model builders to be doubly focused(åŠ å€ä¸“æ³¨äº) on seeking out data.

Demand for data is growing so fast that the stock of high-quality text available for training may be exhausted by 2026, reckons(ä¼°è®¡) Epoch ai, a research outfit(æœºæ„). The latest ai models from Google and Meta, two tech giants, are believed to have been trained on over 1trn words. By comparison, the sum total of English words on Wikipedia, an online encyclopedia, is about 4bn.

It is not only the size of datasets that counts. The better the data, the better the model. Text-based models are ideally trained on long-form, well-written, factually(fact) accurate writing, notes(æŒ‡å‡º) Russell Kaplan of Scale ai, a data startup. Models that are fed this information(feed ä½œä¸ºåŠç‰©åŠ¨è¯,ä¸éœ€è¦ä»‹è¯.She feeds the cat bread every morning. When a baby is thirsty, it feeds more often.) are more likely to produce similarly high-quality output. Likewise, ai chatbots give better answers when asked to explain their working step-by-step, increasing demand for sources like textbooks that do that, too.(è¿™ä¹Ÿå¢åŠ äº†å¯¹åƒæ•™ç§‘ä¹¦è¿™æ ·çš„èµ„æºçš„éœ€æ±‚ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ•™ç§‘ä¹¦æä¾›ä¸€æ­¥ä¸€æ­¥åœ°è§£é‡Š,è€Œä¸æ˜¯ç¿»è¯‘æˆ:å¢åŠ äº†å¯¹èµ„æºçš„éœ€æ±‚,å°±åƒæ•™ç§‘ä¹¦(åœ¨ä¸€æ­¥ä¸€æ­¥è§£é‡Šæ—¶æ‰€éœ€è¦æ›´å¤šçº¸å’Œå¢¨æ°´ä½œä¸ºèµ„æº)é‚£æ ·) Specialised information sets are also prized(å¾ˆæœ‰ä»·å€¼), as they allow models to be â€œfine-tunedâ€ for more niche applications. Microsoftâ€™s purchase of GitHub, a repository for software code, for $7.5bn in 2018 helped it develop a code-writing ai tool.(copilot)

As demand for data grows, accessing it is getting trickier, with content creators now demanding compensation(èµ”å¿) for material that has been ingested(å¸æ”¶) into ai models. A number of copyright-infringement(ä¾µçŠ¯) cases have already been brought against model builders in America. The upshot(ç»“æœ) of all this has been a flurry(ä¸€è¿ä¸²) of dealmaking as ai companies race to secure data sources. In July Openai inked(ç­¾ç½²) a deal with Associated Press, a news agency, to access its archive of stories(æ–°é—»). It has also recently expanded an agreement with Shutterstock, a provider of stock photography, with whom Meta has a deal, too.(Metaä¹Ÿä¸åè€…è¾¾æˆäº†åè®®ã€‚) On August 8th it was reported that Google was in discussions with Universal Music, a record label, to license artistsâ€™ voices to feed a songwriting ai tool. Fidelity, an asset manager, has said that it has been approached by tech firms asking for access to its financial data. Expanding the frontier
There is, however, one source of data that remains largely untapped(æœªå¼€å°çš„/æœªä½¿ç”¨çš„): the information that exists within the walls of the tech firmsâ€™ corporate customers. Many businesses possess(æ‹¥æœ‰), often unwittingly(ä¸çŸ¥ä¸è§‰), vast amounts of useful data, from call-centre transcripts(è®°å½•) to customer spending records. Such information is especially valuable because it can be used to fine-tune models for specific business purposes, like helping call-centre workers answer customersâ€™ queries or business analysts(ä¸šåŠ¡åˆ†æå¸ˆ) spot ways to boost sales.

å¦‚ä½•ç†è§£exist within the walls

There is, however, one source of data that remains largely untapped(æœªå¼€å°çš„/æœªä½¿ç”¨çš„): the information that exists within the walls of the tech firmsâ€™ corporate customers.
åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªå¥å­ä¸­ï¼Œâ€exists within the walls ofâ€ æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ¯”å–»è¡¨è¾¾ï¼Œå®ƒæ„å‘³ç€æ•°æ®å­˜åœ¨äºæŸä¸ªç‰¹å®šçš„åœ°æ–¹æˆ–å®ä½“å†…éƒ¨ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æš—ç¤ºè¿™äº›æ•°æ®å¯èƒ½å°šæœªè¢«å……åˆ†åˆ©ç”¨æˆ–å‘æ˜ã€‚å…·ä½“æ¥è¯´ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨çš„æ¯”å–»æ˜¯æŠŠæ•°æ®æ¯”ä½œè¢«å¢™å£åŒ…å›´çš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œå¼ºè°ƒäº†æ•°æ®çš„éšè”½æ€§å’Œæœªè¢«å¼€å‘çš„æ½œåŠ›ã€‚

Yet making use of that rich resource is not always straightforward. Roy Singh of Bain, a consultancy, notes that most firms have historically paid little attention to the types of vast but unstructured datasets that would prove(è¢«è¯æ˜,ä¸»åŠ¨è¡¨è¢«åŠ¨) most useful for training ai tools. Often these are spread across multiple systems, buried in company servers rather than in the cloud.

Unlocking that information would help companies customise ai tools to better serve their specific needs. Amazon and Microsoft, two tech giants, now offer tools to help companies better manage their unstructured datasets, as does Google. Christian Kleinerman of Snowflake, a database firm, says that business is booming as clients look to â€œtear down data silosâ€(æ‰“ç ´æ•°æ®å­¤å²›). Startups are piling in(æ¶Œå…¥). In April Weaviate, an ai-focused database business, raised $50m at a value of $200m(ä»¥ä»·å€¼ 2 äº¿ç¾å…ƒç­¹é›†äº† 5000 ä¸‡ç¾å…ƒçš„èµ„é‡‘). Barely a week later PineCone, a rival, raised $100m at a valuation of $750m. Earlier this month Neon, another database startup, raised an additional $46m in funding. The scramble for data is only just getting started.
